content:
y 1
												Best in class in terms of the action RPG genre. Yes, this is even factoring in the sacred Diablo 2.Hefty learning curve, but huge payoff if you manage to build out and gear up endgame characters. Having decent survivability and tremendous clearspeed/dps is the name of the game here. The most challenging content the game has to offer will require you not to get oneshot to death whilst also testing your human reflexes.Potion system is of note here - you equip permanent flasks that fill up when killing monsters, so there is a constant gameplay loop of kill/heal/kill/heal. It solves the busywork of other games which treat potions as one-use expendables (and annoyingly requiring you to head back to town for a restock). It also avoids the binary choice of having to immediately pickup health orbs (or not) when it comes to games which drop healing powerups instead.Content is it's strongest suit, with the playerbase largely gravitating towards the short-term 3 month leagues. Each league is a fresh start that allows newer players not to feel left behind. Leagues have also traditionally implemented or experimented with) sometimes drastic changes to the game mechanics (from bounty-style sidequest system in the form of Prophecies to AI-controlled enemy exiles who drop significantly better loot.) The development cycle usually follows an alternating league cycle - i.e. 3month league featuring a major expansion, followed by 3month league featuring minor gameplay shakeups, then a possible 3month league that introduces a brand new storyline Act to the game, and so on.Endgame for PoE can be approached several ways:-aiming for the short-term league achievements within the span of 3 months, these typically earn permanent account-based cosmetic rewards.-filling out the endgame Atlas of maps - this game's equivalent of randomised dungeons.-defeating endgame Map Guardians & The Shaper boss - accessible only once you manage to climb your way up the highest tier maps.-various alternate boss farming opportunities (Izaro, Atziri, Council, Breachlords - each with tier own unique way of getting unlocked by the player.)As for paid advantage concerns, the best selling items would be the extra stash tabs accessible in town as well as the various currency stash tabs that organise your looted currency into piles of 5000 pieces each. Content is not gated by money; free players can access the same amount of content as a paid player. This game is also generally not considered pay to win as there are no paid exp-boost, loot-boost or the other usual suspects in other f2p games. Cosmetics are also another source of developer income.Feel free to give it a go. Game is very rewarding if you manage to stick around.

content:
16, 2016
												The most amazing free to play game out there, depth-wise, gameplay-wise and replayability-wise, no doubt about it.Most people often compare D3 vs PoE, then i remind them that a free to play game is putting out more than twice the amount of content as the other game which you'd spend 70-80 euro(with expansion) to play. It's an obvious choice for me, seeing how Diablo 3 has evolved into the kinda game which you play one week out of the season to restart, play with your friends and then you go back to Path of Exile, because this game does not rely on playing with your friends, does not rely on you playing at the start of a league, or in a league at all.As for the game in it's entirety, i feel that the graphics are a tiny bit lacking, it has a bit of frame rate issues because it's not very optimized, which is getting fixed by pretty much every patch, the gameplay has a bit of repetitiveness to it, but you will never ever learn every single thing there is to the game, it is next to impossible, therefore the depth to the game is huge, the tons of possibilites in skill, class, build & item variation is what makes this game just brilliant. I've played this game since closed beta, and i've probably accumulated around 3-4k hours played in the game, and i feel like i'm very lacking in knowledge when it comes to the game still. It's endless fun, and you will not regret giving it a go, aslong as you're willing to put in the hours to make your character succeed!The amazing game that it is, makes up for any issues that there is, ontop of it being F2P, it's just a flat 10 out of 10.

number of helpful: 415 of 623 people (67%) found this review helpful36 people found this review funny
content:
ry 9, 2016
												So I've put a lot of thought into this review and a decent amount of time into the game - over 400 hours - so please don't disqualify this review if you're a longtime supporter of the game.First of all, I have to say that it is extremely enticing and enjoyable for at least a hundred hours of play. That's undeniable, and, to be honest, pretty great for a whopping 0$ required to play.  That's not to download the game - that's in general, period.  You really CAN'T enhance ingame experience much by paying money, and I for one absolutely love that.Here's the problem with the game - and if you're someone who doesn't plan on doing more than having a little fun for a few hours now and then, this probably won't matter to you. But if you're the kind of gamer who really likes endgame content - read on.  The problems that I have with the game are almost 100% related to endgame content, and deep endgame content at that.#1 - The endgame accessibility.It's relatively easy to begin running maps after a maximum of about thirty hours - even if you don't know what you're doing.  When you are running maps, it's fun, challenging, and the content seems new and fresh.  Maps are relatively easy to get - most players will have hundreds of t1s and t2s hanging around. HOWEVER, this is extremely fleeting.  Once you start crafting your maps, they will very quickly become exponentially harder.  If you're an old player reading this, you'll probably laugh my response off because your gear can easily deal with a t2 map with, say, phys reflect and Temporal Chains.  But to new players, this is extremely frustrating because they can't really gain gear or orbs from these maps but also have an extremely difficult time with them.  The better maps you run, the better loot you get - or is it, really? I would contest that maps t1-t7 have generally the same loot reward, and t7s can be extremely difficult for people who don't have access to the loot of higher level maps.  Sure, you could get extremely lucky and get something great - but that's not likely for most of us.#2. The loot.Yes, yes, as with most negative reviews here, I'm going to whine about the loot drop system.  If you're a new player who likes games in the same style as PoE, you'll probably laugh off my condemnation of RNGesus.  Let me explain: If you think you've experienced RNG walls before this, you have not.  Not even CLOSE.  It has nothing to do with luck. It's probably more likely that you'll win Powerball than actually get an item that you're farming for.  Yes, it's possible that you will get something else that you can sell, but this brings me to my third point - the economy.#3. Trading.Pretty quickly into PoE, you'll probably begin to ask this question: "Why isn't there a public auction house of some sort where I can simply save up orbs and quickly sell and buy loot?"  The answer is that this type of system is extremely dangerous for games such as Path of Exile - and indeed, diablo experienced the repurcussions of incorporating such a system into their game.  The economy is such a huge problem that there have been, since open beta, serious third party clients and websites (Procurement, I'm talking to you) which cater to this demand.  The problem is that there is such a huge volume of loot that it's very, very annoying to scroll through thousands of results for items trying to find out what kind of price the item you're buying should be set at.  And this is a REQUIREMENT FOR ENDGAME CONTENT.  Let me repeat that: it is extremely difficult - or at the very least heavily counterproductive in terms of orb use - to craft your own gear, and it's a requirement to have full tri res gear if you're doing any decent maps.#4. The ability to true create your own build for endgame content.Spoilers! There is no ability for this.  The problem with PoE is that there is a select sect of the population which is SO UNBELIEVABLY GOOD AT THE GAME that all other content scales to them to simply make it interesting - these guys are, of course, the Twitch population.  I'm not talking sour grapes here, I'm quoting GGG - they actually said that "If we created content that would take streamers weeks to complete rather than days or hours, it would take an average player years to complete it."  They've created a paradox.  PoE was hailed when it first came out as having a fantastic loot drop system because it allowed players to create unique builds from "self-found" items.  And again, that's so great - for the first hundred hours. At the very most.  After that, you better pray you haven't focused a summoning build because you thought it was cool, cause let me tell ya, you're going to need a few dozen ex before you can do any maps with good modifiers.  And, of course, cheap builds that you find online won't stay cheap long.  You cannot genuinely build your own character off your gear because in the long run, all gear is trash unless it has very specific modifiers.  If you're running a niche build rather than a meta build, congrats: you just need slightly different extremely specific modifiers.#5. The devs.Last but far, far from least, I'll address the problem that probably most experienced players have with the game.  Personally, I feel that I haven't gotten to enough of the content to actually have this problem, but I recognize its existence and I feel that I should mention it.  If you ARE a player who has saved up hundreds of ex and perfected their gear, ask yourself these questions: "What's my favorite build? What do I like the most? What set of mechanics and gear do I like the best?"  The answer to that question is whatever is about to get nerfed next.  Oh, and it won't be a public nerf. That would inspire far too much backlash.  It'll be a nerf that subtly changes the mechanics so that your character will get absolutely terminated all the time.  If you're softcore, that sucks, and if you're hardcore - well, I hope you like softcore, because your character just got sent there for good.  (Again, this isn't sour grapes - I've just heard this story countless times.)So, to sum things up a bit - Path of Exile suffers from a rather unique affliction.  The endgame content is extremely varied and challenging, with lots of depth and ways to modify and improve your experience - but only if you've already spent hundreds and hundreds or thousands of hours playing the game and have the resources to adapt to extremely varied situations.  Getting your own gear from drops is prohibitively difficult, selling your own drops to incrementally obtain said gear is tedious to an extreme and often will result in you getting scammed or at the very least told 'ur a highballer fggt'.  Even without looking at dealing with the varied situations, the basic endgame content itself is so wierdly difficult that it is very hard to understand without large amounts of research.  Turns out that evasion actually kinda sucks, but hey, at least it's not as easy to get one-shot as with armor, right? Better have both! Oh, damn. That gear looks like it's a few dozen exalts.  Bummer.At the end of my Path of Exile run, I felt like I was no longer actually playing the game.  I was grinding in an unusually unpleasant manner for items which ultimately would be basically useless and chosen entirely at random.  I felt that the game itself had huge amounts of promise but eventually did not deliver.  It is grueling at the very least and indescribably frustrating for most of the time.  It got to the point where I simply did not enjoy the game anymore - the choices were either to suicide into unplayable content trying to get gear that would make said content playable or to re-grind endlessly the beginning map content and get no xp or items.Maybe I'll revisit the game at a later point in time, but at the moment I can't imagine wanting to return anytime soon.

number of helpful: 43 of 47 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
r 19, 2016
TL;DR SUMMARY: 70% modernised Diablo 2, 30% cool new ideas and improvements. A fun, very well-made classic hack'n'slash with good graphics (especially spell/skill effects), great sound and music, dark atmosphere and good story, as well as nicely designed and quite varied locations. Plus of course, the MASSIVE ability tree (which is surprisingly easy to navigate) and a ton of skills/spells to choose from with lots of ways to build your character that actually punishes inexperienced players much less than in most other games. Absolutely worth playing whether you're looking for a few dozen hours of fun or hardcore serious business online gaming, especially that for some reason this game is FREE TO PLAY (and the only purchasable items are cosmetics - lots of them - no pay to win whatsoever).FULL REVIEW: Okay, so it seems most reviews for this game are either "my turtle left me" or 5000h played talking about how good the balance is on the endgame maps after you finish the Merciless difficulty, so this is the nub casual review for people who are bored and went "wat how is this f2p" like I did upon seeing this game.As said above, this game is MASSIVELY inspired by Diablo 2 - similar dark and gloomy overall atmosphere (and a world - or rather region - which is so screwed they'd rather have an apocalypse), familiar-looking red and blue health and mana spheres, familiar-looking inventory that even includes the I/II weapon switching, familiar-looking scrolling dialogues, familiar-looking ability tr-NO WAIT HOLY ♥♥♥♥ HOW MASSIVE IS THIS THING THIS IS LIKE ONE MILLION ABILITIESPath of Exile brings some really cool new ideas and improvements to the table - as justifiably praised in nearly every review out there, the passive ability tree here is ENORMOUS, but after the initial "mind blown" feeling, it's actually quite easy to navigate. It really is very open though, and although few of the passives make a significant impact on their own, in the long run it gives you lots of options to build your character. If you're just learning the game and making it up as you go, it's also pretty easy to change direction or even refund some points (as you get a refund point every once in a while) if you feel you're missing something, e.g. you've put too much focus into damage and now die too easily.Staying on skills and character development, another change I really like are active skills - instead of being tied to your XP level, they come in gems that are placed in weapons/armour in coloured slots (corresponding to an attribute - strength/dexterity/intelligence), which again means that you can pretty much turn your build almost upside down if you want/need to. An awesome addition to that are "support" gems that can be linked to them, which allow for some incredible options and can turn a relatively unimpressive skill into a mind-exploding pocket armageddon. But then, the skills themselves are very diverse and they're mostly both really fun to use and actually useful - there really is something for everyone, and for pretty much any playstyle.You have six although my ninja turtle buddies tell me something about a seventh classes to choose from - three with one primary attribute (Marauder - strength, Ranger - dexterity, Witch - intelligence), and three which are kind of "hybrid" (Duelist - strength/dexterity, Templar - strength/intelligence, Shadow - dexterity/intelligence). I have to complain about the character selection screen a bit, as the descriptions are not very helpful and a bit misleading if you're new - e.g. you can get the idea the Witch is something like a necromancer (which she can be), while she's pretty much the closest thing to a typical mage. In reality, with the way the ability tree and skills work in PoE, each class is very flexible and just knowing what attribute they're focused on gives you an idea what to expect and what playstyle they make sense with.Another clever change, in my opinion, is... getting rid of gold. Yep, there's no gold here. The good old portal and identification (here named Scroll of Wisdom) scrolls are the most basic currency, plus a large variety of different "orbs" that can modify item properties - you can turn an ordinary sword into a Rare Uber Destruction Weapon of Doom and Annihilation. But wait, that doesn't mean getting your hands on powerful items is easy - you have more options to obtain the kind of equipment you want, but it's not easier, as obviously the more powerful orbs are just as rare (if not rarer) as rare items. And this system gets rid of "at first you can't afford to buy a dagger but if you do side quests then you can buy half the planet halfway into the game".The graphics are very nice overall, might not be super-ultra-AAAA-HD-2017 standards, but the game just looks good and as a plus should run smoothly even on not the newest PCs. The combat really looks spectacular and what's very important - not messy and everything is mostly clear even when you're swarmed by enemies or fighting a boss who spams 10 different skills (and this is something that can make or break a game like this). The most disappointing part of graphics is probably... the character selection screen (yep, again), their models don't look very detailed and the first impression wasn't great, but when you get into the actual game, there really is nothing to complain about. The sound is also worth praising - sound effects are satisfying, voice acting is very good and gives personality to characters, and the soundtrack is great and very atmospheric.I personally liked that while PoE does mostly stick to a similar dark and gloomy atmosphere and visuals as Diablo 2, the locations are much more diverse - e.g. some of the forest/jungle locations are actually quite colourful (does not mean they look friendly, though...), but then there are a few places in this game that make Diablo 2 look like My Little Pony. Lunaris Temple. Holy living ♥♥♥♥. Traumatic experience. Plus, the world is a bit more open and there are often several quests to do at the same time which you can complete in any order you like. There are also quite a few side locations, and you can encounter randomly generated "corrupted" areas (quite small with unusual monster types and a boss, plus skill gems you can't find elsewhere) and minor side quests from "masters" who can provide interesting upgrades if you have enough "favour" with them. A minor complaint about locations, though - they are sometimes really quite vast, which means that if you want to explore everything, a) you need to do it in one go as they're semi-randomly generated, b) there can be a lot of mundane running back and forth.The story also deserves a mention - Path of Exile, instead of having just another "super evil demon dude who is evil because he's always been evil; oh wait did I mention evil", instead focuses on people with overblown egos and sick ambitions that get way out of hand. It may not be groundbreaking, but it's very cleverly written, in the way that if you don't care, it completely doesn't get in the way, but if you do, it's interesting and makes you want to keep going and kick the asses of those responsible for this. And there is an interesting plot twist or two...So, is this game anything groundbreaking? Not at all. Is it fun to play? HELL YES. Admittedly, it never really gave me a "OMG WANT TO PLAY POE RIGHT NOW" feeling, but whenever I launched it, I usually ended up playing for 1-2 hours more than I'd planned. There will probably be a lot more hours than what you see above this review.

content:
29
												This game was really good back when the developers had nothing but their life savings and pure drive. Now they have access to money, employees, etc.The game is now, as of this league, (for me) the best MMORPG / MMOARPG on the market.I say do not say something like this lightly, I've played pretty much every MMO released in the west to date. I've been playing MMORPG's since Lineage 1 days. I am disturbed by the design stagnation happening in the current MMO scene. Clone after clone, trope after trope. Why deviate too strongly when a formula works? PoE has so much freaking depth and just keeps getting bigger every patch. More stuff is added to the game than I can keep up with. Which is a good thing, mostly.I'd like to just do a pros/cons bullet list to keep this as short winded as possible. (Ended up being long winded anyway)Pros:* Intense skill customization. You can take a skill gem, socket it in a piece of gear, link other gems with it and change how the main skill functions. * Gigantic skill tree, allowing for very custom builds.* Uniques do very hilarious and weird things, allowing for even more customization* Endless endgame. Endgame comes in the form of maps and currency accumulation. Maps are basically paper portals into other dimensions. You can enchant these maps with mods of your choosing. They are randomized to a degree, but you can tweak them.* I should also mention that maps aren't the entire endgame. Technically you use the "Map Device" to access the rest of the endgame, but there's like tons of bosses and specialty fights.* A very cool currency/enchanting system that is in of itself a goldsink. You use the *currency* items to change... well, lots of things in the game. Items, treasure chests, maps* The more wealth you have the stronger you are, no lockouts whatsoever on any content, love it or hate it* Is going to do away with multiple difficulties for acts, will have one straight playthrough with 10 acts in version 3.0* Devs actually listen and adjust the game both to their vision, and player suggestion* Due to constant additions to systems in the game, has yet to get boring, I've never been so engaged in a game. When I grind, I don't watch netflix. That's huge. * Customer support is on point man, they'll hold your hand through whatevs.* Game is full of secrets. Secret undiscovered vendor recipes, the whole fishing thing, entire game reeks of conspiracy* Lends itself to playing with friends, socializingNeutral:* Uniques in general drop often. Later in the game, you just leave them on the ground. They do this because there's many "Build Enabling" uniques in the game. It still feels weird leaving uniques behind, or vendoring them.* Top tier gameplay (anybody who wants to be efficient and progress) absolutely requires constant trading, unless you play Solo Self Found, which limits prevents you from partying or trading with others. Some days I love trading, it's a fun interactive experience. This game taught me how to barter, haggle. Other days I get really, really tired of trading face to face with everybody. I feel there needs to be an inbetween.Cons:* The depth is also a negative, they keep making improvements to make the game more newbie friendly, just not quite to where it needs to be yet. There's so much to take in, it can be a major deterrent.* The wealth = power thing with no restrictions lends itself to RMT. This really shouldn't be a con though, if you allow players to trade in a game like this, it's going to happen to any game. It's a design issue that can't easily be addressed due to human tendencies. Removing or restricting trading would completely destroy this game though, because it's built for it from the core. * The whole game is a giant flippin' casino. You can smack your first zombie in the game and it can potentially drop an item that would payroll anything your sweet little heart could dream of for a league. This will be moved to the Pros section as soon as I get a Mirror of Kalandra, or T1 unique drop. *sexually implicative wink in GGG's general direction** It's an ARPG, it can still get repetitive* Technical issues, sometimes. Each league and patch is different for me and my friends.* If you're unlucky, progressing as a casual can be tough, depending on your goals.Overall I highly suggest you give it a try, the game just hit peak players this league and I'm sure 3.0 will push those numbers even higher. PS - Oh yeah, and the game is totally free, but you probably knew that.

												An awesome game, with constant improvements and a development team (Grinding Gear Games) that is always really close to the community.From its early steps since today, PoE is becoming better and better. content:
ry 25, 2014
												Path of exile is often compared to the Diablo series, and not without reason.The game viewed as the successor of Diablo 2, from some of the same developers that bought you Diablo 2. I am not exactly a fan of RPGs such as this with dps and varied skills,  but I have fallen in love with the game and intend to play alot more in the future.Path of exile is also not pay to win like Diablo 3 with the Auction House to buy and sell gear, but optional microtransactions that in no way assist you in actual gameplay. You cannot buy anything to directly affect your character statistically, but cosmetically. I also appreciate the upfront nature of the Developers, stating the microtransactions such as portal skins, pets, etc are to support the game, and they deserve it. I am now a fan of RPGs thanks to Path of Exile. I can only hope for the best in the community and will definitely watch the continuous game patches closely. If you want to get into the game in a more complicated way, head over to the Path of Exile website[www.pathofexile.com].I implore you to also view the Metacritic[www.metacritic.com] reviews and other Steam Reviews. They really do tl;dr this review.Congratulations Grinding Gear Games for a game that does not seem like a cash grab or false misrepresentation in a recent streak of badly made or terribly received games.

content:
23, 2015
												Having never played this type of game before (yes I was a CoD only player) It REALLY grabbed me by both hands and shook me out of FPS.It is  COMPLETEY FREE  to play -  ALL of it from start to finish (no if's or but's) you ONLY spend real money if  YOU CHOOSE TO. The game is similar to Neverwinter / Diablo etc. However this is considered  the  pinnicle of them all. I personally believe its quite easy to pick up & understand from your first steps in the game. Any problem with trying to fit a piece of armour / equipment / gem, the game will highlight the 'error(s)' in red. There is an in game global chat that for the most part IS helpful although like any on-line game you will get idiots who give out poor / stupid information etc. There is an awful lot of YouTube stuff out there also to look at.Briefly About the game:-You are an 'Exile' that has been exiled to 'Wraclast' and start your journey to salvation from being washed up ashore. You can first choose 1 of 6 characters, once you have completed the game this unlocks a further 1 more character to choose if you desire. As you travel through each area killing monsters along the way - you gain experience points (XP) this will eventually allow you to level up & 'spend' your XP point, altering your character how you wish to improve him/her. This coupled with the various items that you will find / unlock / win etc. means your character will (hopefully) get better and progress in the game onto harder levels.There is an awful lot of items in this game - some of which you can alter yourself via 'crafting' after playing the game you will get to learn items that will be of use to you etc.Once you reach a certain level within the game you will be able to participate in 'Maps' these are seprate from the main game (again ALL FREE) these can unlock higher level items / rewards etc.Grinding Gear Games also run 'events' at certain times, which you can choose to enter if you wish (again free)The graphics in this game to me are stunning, the effects, the detail, etc this game has it all. Thats why I've donated money when they brought out the new 'Awakening Patch' & paid for lots of footprints/pets/armour/etc. but let me stress I DID NOT have to.Thanks for reading this - I hope it helps make your decision.

												Path of Exile in 2016 holds up. At first I gave the game a postive for it's "simple start" I (and many others) called this game the Diablo III game that it should've been. After a few years since its launch how does it hold up now? It holds up really well. The community and development team is really involve in making this game fun for the "vintage Diablo" fans who like the gritty and horror appeal.Now things seem to be updated in terms of it's combat, magic and rouge gameplay. Daily activites, etc. My only issue is a real ironclad social venue of sorts. It's kind of there but it's a bit clunky and needs a bit of an improvement. If you want a Free-to-Play game with a vintage Diablo apporach. I FULLY recommend this.

												After more than 1200 hours in that game, and $150 over the past 3 years, you really want me to write a review, Steam?Ok.This is a fantastic ARPG. We could argue over and over with numbers, and meaningless "contains hundred of bazilions of thingies that you use to hit other things", but to be fair, this is not what this game is about.This game is about character building. The Passive Skill tree, the Skill gems, the support gems, the link system, the fact that even a white drop is relevant, the constant support, rework, additions to the game, the incredible random based crafting with the game's currencies; those are the elements that make me spend time playing. Those are the elements that make me think about my current build, about what piece of equipment I will need next, and how it will interact with the Unique objects I used, how they unlock a powerful ability, and how they react in a weird way with this skill or that notable passive keystone.Yes, it's a bit more daunting than a lot of other ARPG.Yes, the online only is sometimes a bit annoying.But damn, I've never spent so much time outside a game obsessing about the game than with PoE.It's free, and the only things you can buy are utilities (stash tabs, for the hoarders) and cosmetic items.If you give it a try, I can't be blamed.

content:
r 23, 2013
The Game: If you played Diablo 2, you know what to expect.  Pick a character class and start pointing and clicking until you kill enough things to level up, gain more skills, and get better gear to kill more things!  You build your character around the skills you choose to use, represented as gems that are slotted into your gear.  As you level up, you put points into the massive (and I mean MASSIVE) passive skill tree to customize your character to how you want to play.  The game runs through about level 36, Cruel difficulty to level 54, and Merciless to 68.  The endgame (starting at level 66) consists of "maps" that can drop from killing monsters.Pros: Simple to learn, difficult to master.  The enemies are diverse and always challenging, the maps are randomized, the skills are interesting and fun, and the loot system is incredibly well done.  Joining friends is easy and fun.  Did I mention the game is FREE?Cons: The passive skill tree can be incredibly daunting to new players.  There is no ability to respec your skills aside from starting over, so don't plan on your first character reaching the maps.Conclusion: Play this game!  It's simple to pick up and play at your own pace and consistently rewarding you for learning its more complex mechanics.  Plus its free, the developer ONLY sells cosmetic items, so there is no possible way to gain a gameplay advantage by paying money unlike many other "Free" to Play games out there (see: Neverwinter).

number of helpful: 33 of 42 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2013
												Started playing back in Closed Beta and thought there wasn't a lot to hold my interest. Fast forward 18 months, and I can't get enough of it. Insanely deep skill tree allows for an near-infinite amount of ways to build a character through self-found builds, though these may not work out for beginning players. On the flip side, builds by other players on the official forums are easy to follow and helpful for first-time players. This game is easy to play, hard to master, and very replayable. Rerolling characters in other games, at least for me, is very repetitive and tedious, but not in PoE. Because of the depth and complexity offered by the game, even making a character the same class as your previous one can be drastically different.Currency in PoE is one of key features that sets it apart from other ARPGs. Basic Scrolls of Wisdom allow you to identify Magic/Rare/Unique gear as in other games, but "Orbs" are the de facto currency of the game. Not only do they allow you to modify/reroll your gear, they allow you to trade for other gear with other players.Another stand-out feature of PoE are the skill gems. There are hundreds of Strength, Dexterity, Intelligence, and Support gems that are placed into sockets in weapons and equipment that allow players to use them as skills. Different from other ARPGs that just unlock skills the higher level a player is depending on their class. Not so with PoE. The way skill gems can be mixed with each other, especially with support gems, can really affect how the game is played from build to build. In addition to this, skill gems can level up from 1 through 20 and have increasingly more powerful effects as they level up. An item modifier, quality, also affects gems. Quality further increases the effects of a gem and ranges from 1-20%.The gear/loot in PoE is as extensive as the rest of the game. Standard qualities like magic (blue) and rare (yellow) exist as in other ARPGs, but the implicit and explicit mods on these items is what makes the game interesting. There are so many different mods that exist and affect gameplay as much as the way a character is built or the skills that it uses. In addition to these items, sockets are also an integral part of the game. Without sockets, skill gems would be useless, and without certain sockets, important combinations cannot be achieved. Socket colors in PoE are red (strength gems), green (dexterity gems), blue (intelligence gems), and white (any gem). These sockets can be rerolled using Chromatic Orbs as well as linked using Orbs of Fusing. This really changes up how skill gems can be used in conjunction with other gems, especially later in the game.The story/lore of the game is not necessarily an integral part of the experience, but the settings and locales are decent and the overall art direction and visuals have a real dark feel, which do lend themselves to that story. There are three acts in PoE, up from two that the game previously started with. Each increases in monster level until Act III is beaten, upon which the difficulty goes up (Normal -> Cruel -> Merciless) and Act I begins again. I have not reached endgame maps yet, but they add a lot of content to the endgame experience.Speaking of experience, leveling in PoE requires a lot of experience near the end. Leveling from 1-50 takes little time, and then the experience required jumps quickly as one might expect. Even then, leveling is still not too tedious until much later. My main character is only level 56 so I cannot speak to how long it takes, but other players have reached the upper 90s, so it is feasible. Overall, PoE is a great game at a great price tag: FREE. No pay to win aspects here. If you're looking for an fun, deep, replayable ARPG, this is it. GGG does not mind streaming of their game or even monetizing their game. They value feedback and release patches at a decent clip. In addition to this support, they run races that reward rare currencies or items over a season, though winners are usually the same few, especially in party races. Still fun to play, though.I recommend getting this game...now!

number of helpful: 669 of 1,138 people (59%) found this review helpful118 people found this review funny
content:
5, 2015
												It’s not so much the gameplay that is challenging, but your knowledge of the game itself that challenges you. There are many nuances in the game that you have to learn. First the vocabulary. For example: "5% increased damage" is very different from "5% more damage". And because of this don’t expect to make that perfect char your first go. Especially if you don’t follow a guide. This isn't really a bad thing, but it is not friendly to new players.What is bad are the tags they put on skills. They basically mean nothing. For example "rain of arrows" is a skill that has the projectile tag, but a projectile support skill will not affect this skill. Such as “Greater/lesser projectiles” do absolutely nothing to this skill. It's like GGG wants it to be confusing just because they can make it confusing. I don’t see any other reason for it. It’s why a totem skill can have the tag spell, but things that effect spells don’t effect it. So they make the learning curve even more stupid. And if you go post this as a bug on the forums. You just get trolled and yelled at for being an idiot.The point of the game is to make the most OP character you can. I enjoy doing this, and is the reason I started to play the game. However; even if you succeed in making a character work the way you wanted it too. Don’t expect it to last. GGG has been constantly removing build options. The build diversity has gone way down sense the game first released. And you may not even be able to play your character even remotely close to the way you did before. There is way more to this then simply nerfing stuff. If it was a simple nerf and the build still worked I wouldn’t put this in the review.GGG is on a never ending quest to balance the game. As if things HAVE to be balanced. Meaning anything main stream or popular gets nerfed. In 1.3 it was block. In Awakening it was life leach, and auras. And many other things. Anyways; the point of nerfs where to balance things. But there not balancing things. They are removing options. If block just became less OP instead of them removing most of the different ways of getting it. I would have been ok with it. But the truth is they can’t really balance defensive vs offensive skills. If you want an explanation on that read here http://www.diabloii.net/blog/comments/mad-prophecies-2-defensive-skills But in GGG’s quest to balance these, they instead have made it so you need multiple defensive things going instead of one.For example Chaos damage. Chaos damage has its own special rules. It bypasses your energy shield for free. Is the hardest defense of stat to get in the game, and it is very punishing on specific builds. For some builds the only way around it is to hope for a supper rare and expensive item drop. Recently GGG has upped the item’s drop rate. But it doesn’t really help you get the item if your build needs it. As many maps will just give you snakes or something that does Chaos damage. Even after you re-rolled the map just to avoid the mod of poison damage. This means you’re never going to get the item you need without buying it.Patches are big problems for existing characters. For example: Reduce Mana used to work on auras. But in the awakening patch... Reduced Mana changed so it wouldn’t work with auras or similar gems. They then took the enlightened gem and made it do what reduced mana used to do. This is a huge problem for existing builds. The biggest problem being the color of gem changing. Many people might have corrupted their gear, and can’t change the color gem sockets anymore. Meaning your once level 100 character is now all messed up gear and gems. GGG just expects you to level a new guy. And when they mess up your character they don’t let you redo in game key choices. Like the bandit reward choice. They only give you a passive re-spec. And that is only because they change the passive tree so much. It is usually impossible to leave your old tree in tack.That is my biggest gripe of this game. Many people like this. They think it keeps the game fresh. But for many others... GGG is just destroying builds constantly patch after patch. And you as the player you are just expected to deal with it. Builds come and go. I don’t see this changing, and it will just continue be so. Until the least popular build is the only viable one. Meaning any work you put into creating a build will go to waste. Even if the build isn't that good.GGG don’t like specific build so much that they have over tuned their bosses and other things. For example: They didn’t like life leach so much that they made it so bosses can one shot you. There reason for this is because they don’t want you to take a hit and just be able to heal back up for free. So how do players get around this? There are two options. One is make your char supper mobile and avoid the hit all together. Or make your char supper tanky enough to survive the hit and then life steal back up. That’s right in there attempt to punish a specific build they made it pretty much one of the only viable builds. This just goes to show you that the people in charge of balance at GGG have no clue what they are doing.Also patch changes are not announced before they happen either. However; beta/test realm testers get to play with the changes before anyone else. And most of the major changes can be found in the form of rumors. But the actual patch notes come the same day as the patch. Leaving many builds broken in their wake. And forum jerks going around telling people they had plenty of time to prepare. This gives beta testers a big advantages in many different areas of the game. Like what items to buy, or sell based off upcoming nerfs/buffs. Even way before the patch notes, let alone the patch release. But the biggest annoyance is the race events. Right after a huge major patch like the awakening. They will offer prizes. Such as a laptop to the first person to kill the new boss. They highly show favoritism to a few select people. Weather they realize it or not. So if you don't cheat and are not able to play on the test servers. Then don't expect to win anything. EVER!!!Most people will be happy; until the next patch comes out, and your character is completely gutted again. Because of this I don’t recommend picking up any of the bandit rewards. Just kill all 3. It leaves you with more flexibility; for when the next patch does come out. And don’t spend money on the game. It’s not a matter of “if they will” but “when they will” destroy your current character/build. Very few builds survive from patch to patch. One of the patches actually de-leveled your gems for you. (Yep GGG said you know all those corrupted high level gems you had. Well too bad you have to make new ones now.) This is a game where patches are your worst nightmare.Other things to note are: PVP go ranged or loose. Don’t expect to do groups/parties. The reward isn’t worth the penalties that come with it. Don’t ever corrupt stuff except for gems. Because gems change not just in stats, but in color too. Meaning you will most likely be leveling new ones anyways.Also avoid the forums. GGG will lock your game account for what you say in the forums. Not just your forum account if they don’t like what you say. This is 100% true. You don’t have to believe me. Just read there terms of use. They even locked my account for over a year because of this review.

content:
, 2016
												I don't often write reviews for games. But this game needs it. I installed it a long time ago when it released and played 10 hours or so and said "This game is to indepth for me" and moved on. I came back a few months ago after being burnt out on games like Diablo 3, Torchlight *insert any ARPG besides Grim dawn*. Path of Exile is extreme, its not noob friendly, its hard, builds take time, currency takes time to get, some builds are only viable upon certain rare items, that you either have to pray to RNG jesus for drops or trade for, and they are expensive. And some takes days if not weeks of farming to obtain. That being said, i've never found a game that offers more build variation and replayability than POE. Its a steep learning curve, but its incredibly worth it. This game destroys any other game in its genre. I've played 60+ hours, not sure what my steam time says atm, and have found only a few rares. In diablo 3, rares rain down upon the noobs. The sense of joy and accomplishment when you get a rare drop is almost drug like. This game has revolutionized the ARPG genre IMO. Its almost perfect.So TLDRIf you can can be patient and look up youtube videos, and how to play guides (Since this game has almost zero tutorial on anything), learn from the forums and reddit, learn from your deaths, you will be rewarded with a incredibly well designed game with almost endless replay value, and a type of atmosphere i've never found in any other game of its kind. If you wanted you could develop your character over year of gameplay just trying to min max things.10/10

ry 18
TL;DRThis is a great game. Try it out, its free anyway.Review:Path of Exile is a ftp-Action_RPG game, released 2013 and being under continued development since then, having had multiple free expansions, leagues and content updates. It can be played solo or in a party with up to 5 other people on either soft- or hardcore.Pros:-Free to Play, only cosmetical purchases-dark & gritty style fitting the story and lore-insanely deep and varied skill system-smooth leveling experience-expansive and challenging endgame-interesting and unique currency and crafting system-free trading economy-seasonal leagues with their own twists and challenges to keep the game fresh-regular free content patches-big and friendly community-around 5h of soundtrack-nice looking cosmetical microtransactionsCons:-this will eat your time-start of play can be unimpressive-since this is a always online game, connection issues can be a problem-daunting skill tree-through the leveling process you have to play the same story 3 times in increasing difficulty (changed in the future*)*as of now, the new expansion "Fall of Oriath" has been announced for mid 2017, adding 6 new acts to the 4 existing ones, therefore eliminating the need to replay the story 3 times. (i have a boner)Conclusion:For anyone interested in the action-rpg genre and disappointed by Diablo 3, look no further than this ftp-gem called Path of Exile. Challenging, rewarding and smooth to play, this appeals to everyone: the casual softcore to the min-maxing hardcore player. There is little as rewarding as building up your own character, theorycrafting, gearing, fighting, struggling and finally concquering everything the game has to offer. And then doing another one, thats complety different. And another one.For someone new to the action-rpg genre, don't get scared by the seemingly endless possibilites and mechanics the game offers you, punch through the somewhat tedious first 2-3 hours of the game and enter the realm of the game that will suck you in and never let you out again.9,5/10

number of helpful: 21 of 24 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
y 13
												Path of Exile is an amazingly dense experience with robust endgame content, at the cost of being newbie unfriendly. There is no conventional currency in the game, no auction house, and no skill tree. Instead, a huge variety of orbs which modify maps and items are the base currency, the only way to trade is via a third-party website, and skills are handled by linking gems together to maximize synergies with your passive tree.The passive tree is probably the one thing that everyone has heard about from this game, and I can confirm that it is quite ridiculous. As a now-experienced player, it makes a lot more sense to me, but coming in, 1300+ passive nodes to choose from is a little daunting. You can refund points using some currency, and you gain a decent number of points by playing through the quests, but ultimately you will need to start a new character if you want to radically alter your build.Skills are handled via gems, and you link gems together for cool combinations. You can take a regular skill like Fireball, add cold damage and lightning damage, increase the area of effect, and increase your cast speed. Or, you could link together a series of gems to cast defensive skills when you take enough damage. The sheer number of combinations is insane, and when combined with the passive tree, there are literally hundreds of possible builds out there.The game itself is currently split up into four acts and three difficulties. Completing the last difficulty is somewhat optional however, as by then you’ll probably get to the meat of the endgame – mapping. Mapping is one of the best features of PoE, and it makes the endgame experience incredible. You will eventually meet a character who introduces you to a device which lets you generate portals by putting maps into it. Maps drop from high level enemies, and are divided up into 16 tiers with a variety of special unique maps as well. Each tier has higher monster levels. Maps themselves are just as they sound, a map from the game which you can run. You can use currency to modify maps, adding unique modifiers like monsters casting extra curses, or spawning skeletons, or the player having 50% less armor. There are tons of modifiers and I’m really only scratching the surface. You map to grind gear, grind levels, and eventually work your way to the endgame bosses, of which they are insanely difficult and require powerful gear and a well-designed build.The downside of all of this depth is evident by now – it’s tough to start this game out as a newbie. There is a ridiculous amount of information to parse, and the combination of all the exotic gameplay systems makes it really tough to make good decisions. It’s easy to make a mistake like not getting enough defensive nodes on the passive tree, or not getting enough special keystones to carve out your character, or using bad skill links. It’s easy to create a gimped character who can cruise until level 50, limp to level 60, crawl to 70, and then crash and burn sometime after that. When that happens, your only recourse is to create a new character and begin the grind again.The name of the game here is grinding, and the name of the company is appropriately Grinding Gear Games. This is the ultimate ARPG as far as I’m concerned, and since the genre has always been heavy on grinding, I don’t necessarily mind it. I like falling into a trance with some music and some maps for a few hours.Also, all of this content is completely free. This is a free to play game. That is insanity, and you really have nothing to lose by trying it out. Nearly any character can make it through to the end of the game to finish the story, and if you follow a build online, you can definitely make it to the endgame and perhaps even down the endgame bosses on one of your first characters. Make no mistake, this game isn’t for everyone, but if you’re the kind of person who likes to open up a build calculator, make a plan, and then spend 60-70 hours to see if it works, this is definitely your kind of game. If you played a lot of D2 back in the day, I think this game is worth checking out.

content:
ber 27, 2016
												Play Diablo 2 for years and years and years. [done]*Play Diablo 3 for ~200h and dump it. [200 painful hours of shiny disappointment]Play Path of Exile for years and years and years [to be achieved].------------------------------------------------Yes, PoE has the nice dark touch I am looking for in a game like this (not the cartoonish bull$hit that is D3). There are numerous ingeniously designed areas such as the Mines in Act IV (how the pocket miners are excavated from the walls of the mine) or the The Ship Graveyard of Act I.The Passive Skill Tree looks impressive but is kind of the same... Well, I still have to explore the full depth of the options presented by the tree. Skill reset points are earned by completing quests so you can do adjustments if required. I find this "freedom" to be nice and player-friendly.In the game you level up gems which grant you with passives and active skills. This detour from the other systems is quite nice intro to the genre.The game receives constant updates, new acts, mazes which is a guarantee that you can replay the game numerous times without getting bored. Since I've started following the game closely I haven't seen a single bad update. Just perfect.Another impressive part of the game is the music - the soundtrack must be one of the best OST I've heard in a game and blends nicely to the gaming experience. Some of the tracks are mesmerizing, just turn on the volume and enjoy!Most of all - the game is free. Download it, play it, enjoy it. There are cosmetic microtransactions present. PS.* I just had to say a word or two about D2 and D3 as I do consider Diablo 2 to be a classic in the genre (as Mozart is a classic in the musical genre). Diablo 3 is okish but only the Act V (which comes after purchasing the Reaper of Souls expansion) satisfies my taste. The hero leveling up system is without any depth and after one or 2 play-troughs the grinding losts all it's meaning.My scores for the games:D2: 10/10D3: 5/10PoE: 8.5/10Why 8.5/10 - I do not like how certain items can be traded and how the trading system is implemented. I am reading in the official forums that the devs are working on the issues in the trading system and maybe soon we can enjoy something more structured. TBC

content:
er 21, 2014
												Side Comment:    You are going to hear a lot of people compare this game to the Diablo Series, yet if you have played Diablo, you are going to easily make the same comparison! Have not played Diablo? Then you now have an idea of what Diablo is like. [Congratulations, if you like this you may now just be tempted to buy some of the Diablo games.] Actual Review:    This game has been amazing and it's definatly not like any of your other Free-To-Play Steam Games. As mentioned by the producers, they actually tried to make MADE this game no where close to Pay-To-Play "if" at all. There is an option to spend money on some costume/gear but does not effect your stats which I like a lot. So if you are  Sir/Madam Moneybags  who enjoys just tossing money around, there is an option for that. Graphics are very good, I have yet to find a superior glitch that affects game play and the game runs smooth on my computer. However there has been many complaints about a long loading screen when you open up the game, but I have no problem with it as it actually does not take that long. [Sometimes it helps to click around or minimize it then pull it back up.] All n' all everything is great, the gear is fitting, battle is smooth, and the story is really good. Love that their is seperate pieces that you can find and look into. Another thing I tend to enjoy is that you don't have to deal with numerous of players on the maps which usually causes lag as you run through the maps by yourself (Or with friends). Though if you do enjoy seeing other people, you will be able to see them in the towns and you can chat with them through a Global Chat. That annoys me however as most of them are only trying to sell gear or are being utterly ridiculous. If you can happen to ignore it, you will be fine. To the Haters:    It's unfortunate people try to down this game for silly reasons. Those who don't enjoy the game for silly reasons should understand that it could be because of your computer, you are not playing a genre you are familiar with, you are just too damn picky, or you have nothing better to do. Though I do understand if someone has an actualy reason, then I respect that but is there really a true reason to not like this game?

number of helpful: 19 of 21 people (90%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
ber 16, 2014
												Anyone who liked the old style of diablo games should try this very interesting game, made and maintained by "Grinding Gear Games" Studio from New Zealand. You propably never heared of the studio before, but looking at Path of Exile i hope more good stuff is coming from these guys in the future.PoE is a Diablo Style morpg setting place in a medivial/fantasy world. The game design is done with a lot of love, though to some it might look outdated or old fashioned. The top down style that can only zoom but not rotate can be charming though for all those who hoped for a remade Diablo 1/2 style game for years. Getting into the game is not as easy as with Blizzards famous titles though, the way how trading and currencys work seems a bit weird before you got into the system. There is no ingame currency, but a bunch of different orbs that are interchanged for items at different rates between the players. The system works though, and there is various sites on the web to search gear and items with that you can purchase for orbs you found ingame. Kind of normal for a grind&loot title this game can be very time consuming - i would not advice this title for the casual gamer who wishes to try out epic gear quickly. But the game has means of rewarding you permanently for your spent time, and the permanent updates from the developers with new leagues every couple of month make this title a good choice for the determinated long time player.With a well filled wiki, good forum, a nice community and interesting trading system POE has a lot to offer. Endless variations of character trees and builds are possible - the reward for the time it will take to figure out how everything works in Path of Exiles world. The massive skilltree and possible combinations of skill gems can indeed be a bit too much for some, but if you like depth and don´t mind a bit of work to get started you will propably get addicted to Path of Exile soon. The endgame system where you can run a bunch of different maps that can be crafted with modifiers is something remarkable, and although some ideas of the games wherre Blizzards brainchilt, GGG came up with a bunch of own good ideas to revive the concept of the top down hack&slash game, good old Diablo style.

												This game is utterly fantastic and the most striking thing about it is that it's free. So far I've put in around 15 or so hours and I'm still nowhere near being done yet.If you like these types of games and especially if you have friends to play with online this title is for you.

er 7, 2016
												In my honest opinion, Path of Exile is the true spiritual successor to Diablo 2 | Lord of Destruction.When I originally found PoE in closed beta, I was immediately taken by the team at Grinding Gear Games dedication to their project. I could feel the passion seething from them as I watched videos featuring the Devs expressing their plans for the game and what they aimed to accomplish. As a seasoned PC Gamer who has spent thousands of hours enjoying the Diablo Franchise, as brought to us by Condor, AKA Blizzard North; I was immensely excited for the launch of Diablo 3. In fact, myself, my girlfriend, and two of my friends actually sat outside Futureshop smoking herb and drinking gin (seriously) from about 9PM until the Midnight Launch. We all bought our Collector's Editions (well, I actually bought a box of 6.. knowing how good the extras were and how limited the CE was)... anyways.. we return to our homes excited to begin our journey in the new Diablo... only to find that BlizzTURD and CRAPtivision had fu*ked the doge... and NONE of us could install due to server issues! We literally had to break out Diablo 2 |  LoD to get our fix that night! That was the start to a very very bad launch of Diablo 3... a game that "lead director" Jay Wilson completely destroyed. I personally witnessed many people politely and eloquently express their concerns with the game direction (WoWified... shi7 loot systems.. repetative and linear gameplay.. the list goes on..) get PERMANENTLY banned by the forum admins, actually removing their access to the game they had purcahsed, seriously.. should be CRIMINAL what the blizz dev's were doing.. and I specifically remember one of the BlizzTURDs "Bashiok" who was relentlessly banning people. The inhuman garbage at Blizz responsible for the turd known as D3 have permanently tarnished both BlizzTURD and CRAPtivision for me personally.. and I'm glad they did... because it helped convince me to invest over 600 USD in supporter packs for PoE... I don't regret one cent.. I only wish I had invested more to had my own unique added to the game!Path of Exile is a magnificently complex game with beautiful artwork and an exceptional story line. Amazing what GGG have managed to accomplish, supporting the entire development with ethical microtransactions (cosmetic only, not pay2win)Solid 10/10 game. Magnificent.

content:
, 2016
												Path of Exile is the best free game there is.  Not free as in "I got this game for free to review.", just free.  I've never gotten a game free to review, and I don't think I would want to anyway.  I mean, even though people say it has no influence over their review, can that be possible?  Not if you're a parent, that's for sure.Parents will know quite well the feeling.  You kid comes home from kindergarten with a picture they drew.  "Look, I drew our house!" they exclaim, holding out a drawing that resembles the house in the way Taco Bell resembles food.  But while you're wondering if it was possible the Zika virus was around when your child was born, you don't tell them that they have the artistic ability of a blind baboon, you simply say "That's lovely!" and hang it on the refrigerator next to the twenty other incoherent scribblings they have produced this month.That's the sort of pressure I would feel when reviewing a free copy of a game, but Path of Exile has no need for such shenanigans, it's a totally free ARPG with character customization so detailed that you will just go on the forums and find a build to use.Path of Exile is best summed up as Diablo on steroids, but then it gets banned for using performance-enhancing drugs and goes out and starts its own league, becoming even more successful than it was before.  Well, that's my opinion anyway, and I did get the game for free, but then again, so can you.

												I started playing PoE during open Beta. At first i had my difficulties with the game since i was only playing D3 before. It's FREE TO PLAY and NOT pay to win.I wouldn't recommend this game to everyone. Do you want to play a game that does all the thinking for you? Do you like high-end visual effects? Do you expect a helping hand from the game after you start playing it? Do you want to create a char and stick with it forever? Well then PoE might not be for you. content:
er 5, 2016
												Diablo 2's spirtual successor. When it comes to action RPGs, Path of Exile is king. Despite being completely free to play it still recieves big content patches and even full expansions on a fairly regular basis. The developers are really on-top of things. I've played a little here and there since the closed beta back in 2012, so I've really seen the game be improved and polished over the years. Needless to say, it's still going strong. The game has no "freemium" or "pay2win" aspects, as the microtransactions are almost entirely cosmetics only aside from increased bank size (which is honestly more of a convenience than anything).The gameplay is diablo-esque hack and slash combat, typically you'll have 1 or 2 primary attack skills then an array of support abilities to keep yourself alive and killing things at good speeds.  Bothersome consumable potions from other ARPGs are gone, replaced by convenient flasks that refill as you kill monsters. The actual skills are gems that you can socket into your items, and can be linked together with support gems that can completely alter the ability like "Multiple Projectiles" (Spells have more projectiles, such as turning 1 fireball into 3), "Spell Echo" (Spells are double-casted), or "Chain" (Spells bounce to other targets). Since any class can use any skill gem, the classes instead start on different locations in the gigantic passive skill tree. The passive skill tree, which currently has 1325 nodes to choose from, provides a massive amount of depth to character customization.Items are easily the most in-depth aspects of PoE. Not only does every item have a myriad of stat bonuses and sockets for your skill gems, they can also be modified by "currency items". The Orb of Alchemy which turns a normal item into a rare one, giving it several random stat modifiers, or the Chromatic Orb which randomizes the colors of the item's sockets, are just two examples of currency items in PoE. These special items replace gold as the game's primary currency. Whereas gold is boring and just sits in a pile, these items actually have a purpose, and that ensures they have a significant value in-game when it comes to trading with other players. One of the most saught-after currency items, the Exalted Orb, can often be traded for some of the best items in the entire game to other players.The major aspect I'll mention in this review is Path of Exile's late-game. In many other ARPGs there's a finite end to the game's story, causing you to repeatedly grind the same area endlessly if you wish to level up further after you've completed the storyline. PoE's map system is the answer to that. After you complete most of the game's storyline you get to enter a randomly-generated zone by using activating a 1-use map item that can drop anywhere. These map items, much like normal gear, have stats of their own and can even be modified by currency items. Map's stats will change the monsters or terrain when it's generated, such as "Monsters reflect physical damage", "Monsters fire 2 additional Projectiles", or of course "Area is inhabited by Skeletons". However, the more modifiers a map has, the more loot will drop: encouraging players to increase the challenge for themselves by giving maps lots of dangerous mods to deal with. Maps also feature unique bosses and content not seen elsewhere in the storyline. This gives Path of Exile near endless replayability, in my opinion.So basically if you like ARPGs, this game is for you. My only complaint is not having enough time to play it more often, as these games tend to be quite addictive and can soak up your entire day if you let them!Rating: A

												This game reminds me so much of all the goodness in Diablo 2. So what has this extra to offer?Well, first it's not set in the graphics of the Blizzard universe which makes it quite refreshing, both literally and figuratively speaking. There is no gold and the concept of 'weapon value' has been dropped. So what's important? the gems. They give power and magic and they grow as you advance. They can be resocketed and thereby not lost after first use. The skill tree is very impressive which allows your character to evolve to become very unique. Much of the magic is known but there are plenty new tricks and moves (and totems and prophecies). For a free game very impressive. Monster bashing and fireworks to the max.

content:
, 2015
												edit: I use ggg's client mostly, on which I have logged most of my hours.As Exalted/Champion/Master/Lunaris Supporter, who greatly admires the ethical business model of GGG and their title Path of Exile, my perspective is simply too biased. I advise you take anything I say with a massive grain of salt.This is just a superb action role playing game. It is not for the faint of heart. It does not hold your hand with a tutorial. It expects you to put in some effort. It will be daunting at first. Very daunting.Now the good news- It is not nearly as bad as it looks. That skill tree that looks ridiculously, gratuitously large and terrifying? Yeah, you'll have your bearings around that in a week or two. Probably less. Okay, so there's no gold, and you don't really get what that means? Neither did I... for two days, THEN you'll be Master of Coin, I promise. Two days, on the dot. Less if you drink energy drinks. Yes Path of Exile is extremely complex. One of the most complex games you can find... but that doesn't mean you need to learn every little detail to become good, and it doesn't mean it's going to take a year for that to happen. Just jump in. It takes effort, sure.  But the effort is fun and enjoyable, and you meet new friends along the way who are eager to help. You're a hardcore gamer, amigo. You just don't know it yet. So come join us!If you do, you will be greatly rewarded.Welcome to the rabbit hole, friend. Now, down down down you fall, like many have before. And what lies ahead of you, I simply cannot summarize in review. But I cannot wait for you to experience like I did. Enjoy.Lostman-Edit: And I'm sure this is already known by readers, but this game is legitly free. There are no Pay2Win aspects. Though I have donated quite a bit to the cause and you may not be in a place to show that kind of support at the moment, I will have no advantage over you in the game other than my hair will be a tad shinier (who cares?).

number of helpful: 30 of 46 people (65%) found this review helpful17 people found this review funny
content:
4, 2015
												*Gets handed a Microphone*What...Path of Exile? Wh- NOW!?...Okay...Uhm...It's better than Diablo! 10/10....What more do you want from me at this short no- WE'LL DO IT LIVE! W-WE'LL DO IT LIVE DAMNIT!#I Want Malachais SpikeANYWAY, What's Path of Exile? It's Diablo, done right, pretty much. Yeah I know some of the fanboys are PROBABLY going to downvote me for this, but it's still true. The game is free, and is more dynamic and polished than Diablo ever was. That can be a bad as well as a good thing...With Diablo you don't get in-game stores cause you already paid for it a-...Wait you can buy stuff for it on battlenet?...Well...Uhm...okay!The game's pretty much you picking one of 7 different classes...From brute monster dudes to a creepy witch gal, and then you get pitted against four chapters of various horrifying and SUPER edgy monsters, while being forced to tackle the most INTIMIDATING SKILL TREE THAT YOU WILL EVER EVER SEE FOR AS LONG AS YOU LIVE!!![i.imgur.com]. Seriously, it's flipping mind blowing! There are dozens of different paths to take and things to do and stuff and what have you! It's outrageous! And to add insult to injury: There's no tutorial what so ever! After getting to a certain point in the first playthrough, you unlock a jack of all, ace of none character, named Scion, who's pretty much a blank slate character. Do what you want with type of deal.The graphics are a-okay and it actually gives you a wide range of spec requirements...the recommended is nice and high and lets even the toughest rigs get to make the game into a gorey HD experience, while the minimum are so low that even the worst old crappy laptops(Like my own) can play it with little to no complications!Once you've completed the game on normal difficulty....you...GET TO PLAY THROUGH IT AGAIN!...This time on cruel difficulty, and then merciless!!! Yes, you have to backtrack the same stuff you just did if you want to level past 35-40 -.- Cause thats when you reach the last bit of chapter 4 and the game starts from scratch 1 difficulty level higher.But it's okay cause you'll NEED to know how this stuff works anyway! Normal difficulty is more like a 'let me show you how its done' stage, and cruel difficulty is actually the INTENDED difficulty of the game! Or that's the feeling I got from it, anyway.So now lets do some pros and cons...Pros:It's better than Sakura ClickerYou have the most freedom skill wise than in any other game that I've ever seen.Large assortment of classes to choose from, including one ace of none jack of all character to unlock.Very large community, which is commonly adultThe game is INSANELY gorey and kind of horror based. Lots of impaled corpses and body parts and literal RIVERS of blood. If you're a gorefest lover, you'll ADORE this game!Naked golden statue women with really nice golden asses...BIG plus for that one.PvP is a thing!Crazy difficulty curve...Easy at first, IMPOSSIBLE to solo at the end.A real e-peen fertilizer! You feel you have a boner that could lift your desk when you're wrecking parts of the game that shouldnt be soloable, by yourself!You can raise the dead to fight for you, then make them explode when they die, then raise the dead who just died to your zombie minions...It's AMAZING!!!Cons:The currency system is a complete mess...It's based on 'orbs' and there are literally 15+ different orbs to keep track of, each more valuable than another and WHAT value they exactly are switches from day to day and from person to person, so you might buy something for 10 regal orbs but can only seem to sell it for 5 etc.How good you are is RNG based. When you get a good piece of gear, it might not fit your needs exactly(You might do lightning dmg mainly and the piece has cold dmg!). So you use an orb of chance or whatever it is to change the attributes of it to fit your needs....And you might end up making it WORSE, like putting strength on some mage gloves or something stupid like that! Being good in this game relies a LOT!!! on luck of the draw.Repetitive as all hell.You play through the game...next difficulty...Play through the game...NEXT difficulty...OH there's an event! Make a new character, play through the game, event ends, new character again, new league to get better get...Play through the game, next difficulty, league ends, character gets put in hardcore league....If character died, character's bumped to standard league. Make new character etc. It's the same exact stuff over and over again.Bit of a random storyline.It's kinda hard to follow the lore of the game, as it's all kind of just thrown at you as you go along :\ Unless you sit and waste 30 seconds - 3 minutes reading dialogue from NPCs, you will have NO IDEA whats going on, or why Merveil has to die, or why Malachai is a grade A ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, etc.Other than that, the game is, for its few, not super crippling flaws, a really good one, and I do indeed recommend it.

number of helpful: 17 of 23 people (74%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
y 7, 2015
-Quick Review-Path of exile is a free to play dungeon crawler which reverses skill points and abilities, you can always change your abilities, but you are limited in changing skill/trait/build points. Please note, I feel that dungeon crawlers are probably my weakest style to review, because they all start to feel the same to me after awhile, put in a few words, I enjoyed this one the most out of Diablo3, Torchlight 2. -Detailed breakdown review- Story:  Hail Exile, you are on Wraeclast, a bloody and dangerous land full of treasure, loot, monsters, Goatmen, and various other enemies. I just remember Goatmen, because I feel like they're following me around in dungeon crawlers. *looks out window*You won't be playing this game for its story, while the game does provide fully voiced dialogue with the various npc's, my best friend never gave me time to listen to the dialogue, so we just kept dungeon grinding and skipped the conversations. The basic gist of the story is: You're an exile, go get your revenge, got your revenge? Restart! You're an exile, go get your revenge, got your revenge? One more time! You're an Exile, go get your revenge, got your revenge? Yay! Now you need to map grind. Game Play: As with dungeon crawler games you control movement with clicking, you're in the above view watching your exile run all over your screen. additionally you can set various action butons, 1,2,3,4,5 are quick buttons to use flasks. you can bind left, middle or right click to different attacks, as well as several keys on your keyboard.You also face some npc's that are a different color or have a different health bar, indicating they're  cooler than other npc's; if you see these smug npc's be sure to slap them and tell 'em Atratzu sent you. But, on a more serious note, they have different abilities, and attack types, sometimes they can leap, sometimes curse, other times they shoot hyper beam at you. Achievements: there are really two types of achievements, the ones regular people can do, and the ones that will require a commitment to the game. This game is meant to appeal to hardcore gamers, there is also a hardcore mode.  Price:  The game's free, you have no excuse to not at least try it sometime. If you want to look like a badass, then you need to pay real money to get the aesthetics or bank space. But if you are just looking to play a dungeon crawler for a little while, go for it. Conclusion: Story: What story? Why are we killing this guy again? because that random guy said so? Okay! *murders face*. Game Play: Fun, but unforgiving in the skill point tree. Achievements: Mostly challenging grindy or RNG achievements. Price: Free, for everything else... there's Master card.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update April 11, 2015:small grammar, spelling, and punctuation fix

number of helpful: 14 of 19 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2013
												I never thought I'd love Path of Exile as much as I love Torchlight 2. I love the idea of the huge passive skill tree and Final Fantasy style active skill system. Instead of providing a linear active skill tree, skills in Path of Exile are itemized onto "Skill Gems". These gems can be activated by socketing them into your equipment. With the addition of a "Support-Gem", you can make your own unique skill. For example a simple fireball gem combined with "Multiple Projectiles" gem will turn your fireball skill into multiple fireballs. You can experiment and make your own active skills. There are thousands of combinations of skills and augmentations.The most important thing -- the game is completely free! PoE offers ethical micro-transactions. There is no pay-to-win element. People can buy only cosmetic items for real-world money.If you are going to give this game a try then remember to pre-plan your build or get ready to create new characters many times because "Math of Exile" punishes casual players.
