content:
, 2014
												If you enjoy action rpgs - especially Diablo 1 and 2, then you must give Path of Exile a try. I have been a gamer all my life, and Diablo 2 was the game I have regularly played the longest (I think around 3 years).I was very happy with PoE when I started earlier in June - it really is a spiritual successor for Diablo 2. You can play through it by yourself, although it can get pretty difficult that way. If you like Arpg's with A LOT of depth, I would highly recommend it. I would also highly recommend NOT playing it, if you value your time - as it can become supremely addicting. The nice thing about the online component is that there are leagues, like Standard and Hardcore, and even then there isn't any "true" permadeath, as dying in Hardcore league will simply transfer your character to the Standard one. You share your loot among ALL characters in the SAME league.There are also Ambush and Invasion leagues. Ambush is considered softcore because it's actually a lot easier - there are "strongboxes" that usually contain better loot but are guarded by stronger enemies. Invasion is hardcore, enemies and bosses from other areas (called "instances") will come into your current area periodically. Death in Invasion puts your character into Standard league.The nice thing about these leagues is that it only runs for 4 months. After that, your characters are put into standard league. This usually results in "junk" loot, where your standard chest will have hoards of loot. This also resets the economy, maintaining a constant level-playing field for newcomers.The PASSIVE skill map...oh dear. If you've played Final Fantasy 10, it's similar to the sphere grid. The customization of skills is absolutely ridiculous. That being said, the skill map is fantastic in that it is accessible to ALL classes. The only difference is that each class starts off in a different section of the map. For example, the Witch (mage) will be closer to intelligence-related nodes, while the templar will be close to the intelligence and strength ones (which also are elemental dmg/res and staff nodes). Near the end of the game, you will unlock the Scion, who starts off at the center of the map. In this sense, you can even have a Ranger summoner who uses a Templar staff, but it would be much less viable and efficient in terms of maximizing your area of the grid. The nice thing about your character resetting to Standard league is you get FULL respec points, so you can change up your build and experiment. There is also official (and unofficial) skill maps that let you play with the nodes and give you good feedback on how your character will look on pen and paper.Once you get a general feel for the game, focusing on one skill is very accurate - best advice for new people is to research the skills (available on the website) and decide which one you'd like to use. There are unlocked active skills when you level up, instead, all active skills come in the form of skill gems. Most equipment have skill gem sockets, and there are items that allow you to reforge/add skill gems. So, a Witch summoner would have blue gems inserted into blue sockets. There are also support gems that will affect any gems in linked sockets, for example multiple projectiles linked to fireball so you shoot 2-3 instead of 1. These also level up while you level up (dont have to keep using it), so a common technique is to equip gems you also want to level up (but not necessarily use) into your 2nd equipment swap because they still gain exp. Just like the passive skill tree, any class can equip any gem, so long as you meet the requirements (level and intelligence/strength/dex depending on the type of gem).It is totally possible to beat the game playing casually and not worrying about both the passive tree and skill gems too much, but after that, the next two difficulties will probably be next to impossible (especially if you're running solo). Players can only join your instance if you are partied up, so you don't have to worry about people coming to your game and aggro-ing you suddenly.EVERYONE will make a mistake on their first character. The goal is to experiment and see how you like to play. My good friend that introduced me to this quit on his level 60+ character because he realized he screwed up. I really, really love planning out my skill trees and deciding which one to use.Storywise. . .I'll be honest - I only have a vague idea of what was going on, and I've beaten the game. Granted, PoE was originally a 2 chapter game with 4 difficulties - now it is a 3 chapter game with 3 difficulties. The story seems very tacked on, and the flavor comes in the form of these stones that you can find throughout the game and read. There have been suggestions to let the lore read aloud as you move around (ala Diablo 2 {unless I'm remembering incorrectly}), but instead you have to stand still and read it (or not). Not the best, engaging story IMO.Races. Omg races. I have stayed up til 2am just to see what the next sales on steam will be. I have also stayed up til 2am just to participate in a race. A race is a short game where you make a character and try to complete goals (most commonly attaining a certain level tier), before the time (ex: 1 hour) is up. You get points, and after receiving enough points, you unlock an item that can be retreived by any character in any league (once). I'm saving all of mine for the next Ambush league (ends and restarts in July).The gameplay - very, very fun. Reminds me so much of D2. The aesthetics are very good, armor is cool to see. Not at all P2W, all microtransactions are completely aesthetic, although you will probably want to buy more tabs for the chest.Definitely recommend!

content:
er 8, 2013
												The spiritual and true heir of Diablo 2.  It seems a little dull in the beginning, but the later zones and acts are substantially better in terms of graphics, level design, monsters, and boss tactics. A genuinely challnging game that is nevertheless fair and heavily skill-based. Crafting, lack of gold currency, an impressive skill tree, and an extremely flexible character design (no "class items") add additional spice. The only downside is the drab start that may turn off people before they get pulled into this game. Also, no full respec option, but whether that's a plus or a minus is up to you (you do get skill removal points and can also farm more). For any Diablo lover, this is the game to play -- it has ascended to the ARPG throne, without a question.

content:
er 26, 2013
												This game is just...everything I want in a Diablo styled Action RPG.  The unique skill gem system, the amazing stat tree, everything is just so well put together.  The tree is so large that almost every character in the game is unique, and there are what seems like an endless amount of combinations.  The support gems are also nice.  For example, the Spark gem with a fork support gem would cause the spark to split off into 3 directions.  Or the Life Leech support, which leeches life on a hit as long as you use the supported skill.  The loot system is also fantastic.  Unique items are difficult, yet not impossible to find, and if you find something good for a different character, you can just stash it for them.  All in all, it's a very unique game and many things it does, it does well.

												A quality Free To Play Action RPG. It has a skill system similar to Final Fantasy VII's materia system, where you put a skill gem in a piece of equipment to gain access to new abilities, or passive bonuses that can link to other skill gems in the same piece of equipment that has linked slots. As well as getting 1 passive skill point per level up to spend in a skilltree reminiscent of Final Fantasy X's system, minus killing enemies for AP.You get to play through a well made campaign with several acts without paying a dime. If you're a fan of games like Diablo II, Torchlight, etc, you should definitely give this game a try sometime.

er 29, 2014
												I've been playing Path of Exile since its Beta release, and i have pretty much nothing but positive reviews for this game. Infact, this game is so geniusly built i would actually be proud to say this is what Diablo III Should have been. (Sorry Blizzard, comming from a huge Blizzard game supporter in my past) The customization and variations of this game are so vast beyond anyones wildest dreams, I absolutely love it. Your currency system is GENIUS as well, its exactly what a game like Diablo lacked. Gold became really useless in late Diablo 2 gameplay, even in D3. It was really sad. Your currency system designed here keeps every currency in demand. No matter how far into the game you are.Ontop of this overwhelmingly amazingly positive review, you keep releasing more and more things that will keep this game alive for years to come and that truely takes talent.Leagues- BrilliantMore Skill gems!!! WOW EVEN MORE CUSTOMIZATION TO YOUR TALENT TREE BUILDS!!!!Reward incentives.And yet again, if you could put anymore cherries ontop of this wonderful cake that you already have, the game is FREE! Yet again, your genius plan works. Microtransaction is the way of the future! You keep huge respect for your games F2P Scene but yet if a player wants to spend a little money to customize their Character, they can by choice.MY ONLY COMPLAINTS about this game  (Which is extremely hard to fix) is your rubber banding system. I dont know if it is because of lack of servers around the world or not, but it has adressed me some serious problems when playing Hardcore mode in your game. And i know that is disheartening to any gamer. My other complaint, which really isnt even a complaint, is this games graphics. Its not a deal breaker by any means, but  feel like it could use some improvement.All in all I would rate Path of Exile a 9/10 since you seem to keep improving this game further and further.  You have my highest respects, one of the best RPGs to date.

												Very good, but beware! This game is not n00b-friendly at all (things could do with a lot more explanation).In PoE, you play an Exile who just landed on the coast of Wraeclast. From there, you will fight your way across the continent and find what's behind the corruption of the land. To do this, you use skill gems that you can socket into your equipment, different kinds of orbs that enchant your stuff and spend points in a massive passive skill tree. The skill tree in this game provides very few skills, because the majority is available as skill gems (that you can swap in/out at a moment's notice).I didn't try to use the global chat (too noisy), so can't really tell if the online aspect is good or not.

content:
24, 2015
												At the time of the review I have about 700 hours logged on steam version. Path of Exile is  a hardcore action RPG with a lot of depth. It will most likely take a while to get in to and it is not suited for quite a lot of gamers. However, this game is absolutely fantastic. Pros and cons can be subjective, so I'll just point out main points.-Hardcore. Can be a heaven for hardcore gamers and a nightmare for casuals. Not recommended for your first ARPG.-Free-to-play but not pay-to-win. GGG's microtransaction system is very fair. Almost everything is cosmetics and nothing in microtransaction store gives anyone an advantage.-Realistic gritty graphics. I personally love the graphic and art style, but it is highly subjective.-Music varies from "meh" to absolute blasts. From boring lullabies to beautiful symphonies. -Sound design is pretty solid. Good voice acting and realistic sounds.-Support is great and quick. I personally had great time using it.-Game has classes, however, the class only changes how your character looks and from where he/she starts from the skill tree.-Characters can use any skills or items if they have required stats. Skills are skill gems that can be socketed in to items.-Ridiculously flexible and huge skill tree. You can make thousands or possibly even millions of builds with the tree provided. Skill tree consists of little upgrades (For example, 0.3% life regeneration or 12% more physical damage.)Some people don't like this, but those small upgrades stack fast, I personally love the freedom of the skill tree.-Game is based on leagues, so there will be different leagues where you can create a new character and try new things.-Lot of equipment variance, you can find, buy or craft items perfect for your build or even multiple ones.-Trading is decent but should be worked on. You either need to yell to chat or use 3rd party websites to make trades. Game has no auction houses or player shops in-game.-Leveling can be quick or slow, depending on build and skill. Max level is 100 and you can reach level 70 in 10-15 hours.-The game has 3 difficulties, Normal, Cruel and Merciless. You will move to the next difficulty after completing storyline. Story currently is composed of 3 acts (4th one is coming soon) and you complete those acts in each difficulty. This can be very boring, since it can feel like the game is repeating.-The endgame is a map system. You can craft mods in to your maps to make them fit your build or your needs. I personally love this system, since it offers a lot of variance, varying difficulties and different experiences.-The D-sync (Should be fixed in the Awakening expansion). Basically, you will be off sync from the game and you might in a different position than your character seems to be on your screen. This can and probably will cause a lot of deaths and frustration, but should be getting fixed soon. (Only thing that has really caused me frustration in the game. Glad to see it going)I might have forgotten some main points...Overall, I think Path of Exile is a fantastic game by a fantastic company and I recommend it whole heartedly.Edit: Now at over 3k total and the Atlas of Worlds expansion is fantastic.

r 28, 2014
												If you like gear based grinding games then this one is for you.  Let me start out by saying that I enjoy a hard challenge and have to play on hardcore, where you only die once and then you drop down to standard mode (softcore).  Any character that drops down like this is dead to me, never to be played again.   I wasn't sold on this game at first as I got sick of dying at lot :) .  Lately been playing it a lot and more and now I understand the boss mechanics accept that I will die at some point but it's just a matter of how long I can last.With a massive skill tree where you can spend 120 skill points from 1350 skill nodes there is a large amount of replayability.  Even though there is a lot of repetition in replaying the same maps over and over (until you beat Merciless difficulty and move into endgame randomised "maps") it's the character customisation that keeps me coming back.  Give it a shot, I think it's worth it.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2016
												Basically this excellent game is a free to play Diablo 2 with a character improvement system that is QUITE REMINISCENT to the Sphere Grid  from Final Fantasy  X. Except that the grid itself is... ridiculously big. And if you are just playing casually, you can use it to develop your character in ways you want.But if you are fairly serious, you will need to find out  ways to actually build effective and efficient characters, having entire trees planned beforehand.And then you will need to get quite lucky or trade successfully, because skills are not bound to a character. That is both the game's greatest strength and greatest weakness, in my opinion. The skill system is  INCREDIBLY flexible, being more similar to FF7's materia system than anything else. Skills come in the form of "virtue gems", which you get to slot into items with the appropriate colored slots.Said gems mostly come in rare, random drops. You either need to trade for them (easier now since there are vendors that do sell some useful gems now), win  many of them on quests, or trade with the community.Extremely flexible, and if diablo 2 gameplay mixed with FF7 skill systems and FFX sphere grid character growth sounds interesting, you will probably devote many many hours in this title.The ingame shop is only for cosmetic items, storage space and character slots, as far as I know, so there is no such thing as a pay to win scheme in this game.EXTREMELY recommended.

content:
er 13, 2013
												Current state : if you can get pass the performance issues it's a great game, i still wouldn't recommend it until they fixed that side2016 update:i wanted to write a full breakdown of changes between the last 2 years but i don't have enough space so i'll go fast on each point :1) desync fixed2) performance still sucks3) the last expansion was released too early full of bugs4) challenges can be completed with less farming and got improved5)trading got improved a bit , but idd still love a Self Found League6) balance : powercreep is of the charts expecting changes in next league7) no one cares about PvP so they aren't gonna focus on it anymore, not surprised here------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------original review:First thing i should mention is that this review doesn't takle what Path of Exile does best, but what a released game should be and shouldn't.   -> 1) Desync there is no need argue about it's presence in-game, we know it's in the game on a daily presence and that it will affect your gameplay.     ->* skills that will make you desync : flicker strike , cyclone; since you move when you use these skills usage of "shift"(to stop you from moving on server/client side) will not help       ->* gameplay that will make you desync : even though it's present overall in the game the most desync part of the game is Dominus fight especially his first part, if you try to kite and move behind cover you will desync at least once per fight , it won't kill you in 90% of the cases but nevertheless is still annoying as hell . Desync is responsable for many hardcore deaths every day     ->* server side problems combined with desync, last time this happened 4/6 players died from a hardcore party, one of them was level 90 ->2) Performance :    ->*depending on your playstyle:      ->**if you play alone : in town, eternal laboratory or any other empty place i manage to get 170+ fps when you start playing the game it will go to 60-70, if you are doing a end game map with some special mods it will drop to 30-50       ->** if you play in a party: the performance will be lower because there is more stuff going on but some times it will go to "1" when certain skills are used   ->* Death animation will make you drops fps if you kill large packs of monsters   ->* range attacks and spells : discharge, lightning arrow, fireball, freezing pulse, ice spear, poison arrow... will lower your framerate but only in end-game or when used in a combination with cast on crit   ->* the game will just not work properly if you have a " creative sound card"    ->* cpu bound : changing your graphics options will  not make a big difference in fps gain or loss during fights, even if you have 1 fps the game will not use more than 30-40% of your graphics card (depending on how powerfull it is)  ->3) Bugs: yes we know that every game has bugs but     ->* in a end game focus on map drops you should work on fixing them first :      ->** monsters stuck behind walls and cannot be reached : this happens a lot on Shipyard map (level 77 top tier map, 1 level below max map level) and if you didn't kill last 5-10 monsters you might just not get a map drop, when you didn't get any map last few monster have a good chance of droping 1 or even more maps      ->** you are kicked from the server and cannot join the map again, these happened twice in a almost half year period     ->* every patch is plagued with game breaking bugs, last time they had to roll back because more than 1000 chars died on hardcore. Even the devs will tell you not to play soon after a patch is released especially on Hardcore  ->4)Challenge system and how it affect the gameplay and drops :   ->* since they added the "challenge system" we saw a change on where the unique item required to complete a specific challenge drops : you have Kaom's heart and shavronne's dropping only from level 76+ maps, before you could get them by just farming level 66-67 content for a few months, the price was also lower.    ->* the only reason they added map only unique item drop is because they had 61 people completing challenges before so they wanted to lower that number    ->* only challenge in getting 8 out of 8 challenges completed is getting all the unique items, to get them all you will need at least 250 exalted orbs, let's say you are playing like 7 hours a day 7/7 days a week even you make 10 exalted orbs a week it will take you at least 25 weeks (keep in mind that the first few weeks you will invest most of your currency in upgrading your gear and progressing rather than storing it)   ->*this is not something skill based, if you speak about skill it's not even rewarded in or outside the game. Chris will go and interview "popular" streamers instead of "skilled" even though they are pretty popular in the Path of Exile scene, not even when we had the first player reaching level 100 (max in Path of exile)   ->* there is a frequent joke made on forums that the only hard part of this game is the Magic Find slider, how much can you get without big drawbacks  ->5) Trading :  ->* you hated action house in other games? well you will hate this trading system even more, there is no proper way to search on forums, both forums and trade channel is filled with spam , people just stay in town and buy/sell both currency or items, this is the same problem Diablo 3 had where people played "the action house" instead of the game because it was the best way to get best gear in-game ->6)Balance :   ->* the new monsters hit harder compared to older monsters even though they use the same skill: a monster made before does 5% the monster does 20-40%   ->* moba style of balance changes to skills    ->* even though it was promised in different interviews that there will not be nerfs when someone found a cool builds, that does seem the case, and it went as far removing a skill from in-game (Phase Run) even though it's still on the webpage and a  flask , which was later added back with a nerfed version   ->* at the release 9 unique items were nerfed    ->* every new unique item or skill gem has a drawback, you can say that unique items have at least 2 drawbacks now   ->7) Promises for the release:  ->* we where promised that they will take feedback from players on their forums , but the respond more on Reddit rather than on the main forum, and even with all the feedback they still will do whatever they want, making you just waste your time, it's not just me saying this there are a lot of people that playes  this game since Closed Beta and have the same opinion ->*Private leagues : still waiting on news , it seems they completly forgot about it ->* PvP : might be delivered in next patch , was promised in the release patch like it was for Diablo 3 ->* Trading system revamp : again pushed back to god knows when ->* Act IV : pushed back to march 2014 ->* weekly updates : now updates will be made every 2 weeks ->* optimization : still waiting on it ->* Clans/guilds : you have a guild tag and a chest that lags every time you put or take something out of it, there is actually no reason to have a guild chest unless you want to troll people with the most worthless items you can find in-game . there is no guild banner or shirt or any customization whatsoever to it ->* custom rogue exile through steam workshop : again no news about itAt the current state of the game i wouldn't recommend it, maybe in 1-2 years it will be better but until then my journey in Path of Exile

content:
, 2015
												Stunning visuals, addictive mechanics, and neat functions. Path of Exile, at first, is a solid experience, especially since the game doesn't cost a dime, and sports ethical microtransactions. No pay to win here, which is a big plus in my book. Path of Exile was meant to be the Diablo 2 successor that I've always dreamed of... but is it?The first playthrough, as previously stated, was solid. The character progression tree is intimidating at first, but can be mastered over time. Skill gems offer a neat twist to the tried and true "Diablo" formula. There's plenty of strategy to implement here. I thoroughly enjoyed the standard difficulty.But where did it all go wrong?The second you beat the first playthrough, it all goes downhill. "Cruel" difficulty is terribly unbalanced. You will breeze through regular enemies, but once a rare or unique enemy appears, you are promptly one-shot-killed. Heck, even a select few normal enemies can one or two shot kill you. Regardless of how you die, you will lose 5% of your experience on this difficulty. This function is archaic, and fundamentally flawed, completely and totally. Diablo 2 did this, except the game is 15 years old, and 15 years is enough time for game developers to realize "yes, players hate this, and it kills progression, and thus, the entire gameplay experience". Grinding Gear Games didn't get the memo, it seems. Regardless, once this penalty kicks in, the game becomes a sluggish, boring grindfest where you struggle to level up in the face of unbalanced enemies and "cruel" penalties. My desire to play was crushed once I was met with this awful formula. As an insult to injury, your elemental resistances are reduced by 20%, which makes one-shot deaths even easier.Due to this massive difficulty boost, you REQUIRE a build to survive. There is no free reign to design your character anymore; you must now look to the net to guide you. Unlike the first playthrough, progression is limited to this, and the experience is totally drained out and dried up because of it. Progression is a massive part of what makes this game and others like it fun, and with this unnecessary and poorly implemented slippery slope added, it becomes entirely tedious and stale.... a grindfest (and it isn't even a traditional MMO). It essentially becomes a game like Dark Souls - a game for masochists. A game where you have to throw an unnecessary amount of time, effort, and research into it to enjoy the bare basics of the game. To even scrape by.These are the reasons why I do not recommend this game. The beginning showed LOTS of promise, but once your first playthrough is up, there's no point in continuing. There's no compelling story, no memorable characters, and the first playthrough,the Dark Souls-like gameplay is mediocre at best, and rage-inducing at worst.Thankfully, I didn't spend a dime on this gameplay-flawed package. I hope you don't spend any on it as well.

I delete every meta unique I find because it is unethical to keep it. When my character dies, I delete every item in every stash tab because it's not true ethical SSF hardcore otherwise. I Vorici break every six-link I land because it is unrealistic to ever six-link an item in true ethical SSF hardcore. I skip the Labyrinth because Ascendency Classes are unethical powerhouses. Every time a Vaal Orb drops, I immediately use it on a randomly equipped piece of gear to increase the challenge. I've had global chat and trade chat disabled since I got my beta invite back in 0.9.2d, the Merveil fireball optimisation and curse duration patch, because player interaction gave too much advantage. I read and listen to every lorestone, notes, books to fully immerse myself in the true ethical SSF hardcore experience. I've stolen at least a dozen credit cards from my parents to pay for the 3,250 normal stash tabs that I have to show my support for GGG and the true hardcore game that they have developed. It deeply saddens me that PT left, he was the only one that spoke only truth. Why do you self-proclaimed SSF hardcores even try to pretend that you're truly SSF hardcore? You make me ♥♥♥♥ing sick.

y 29, 2014
												The best thing you can say about this game is that its free and when I say free its 100% free in no way will not spending hold you back at all.That being said why play a free game if its no fun? The game as most of its type is grindy but thats fine if the story is good or the dungeons varied. In Path Of Exile the story as far as I got was well not a story rather just a few npcs who would make a funeral more depressing and you keep finding yourself skipping the text before you fall asleep.The Dungeons are no better, maybe the lead dungeon designer got bored after making three types (underground, forest, coast) and thought no-one would notice.The lvling up system is quite interesting using a final fantasy type spider system allowing millions of different combinations which would allow for hundreds of styles of play but in reality only a few will work for every character, so caution is required as making a mistake on your leveling pathway could mean you end up with a dud many hours later.Expect for that it really is just a standard ARPG with poor graphics that even free is not recommand over Van Helsing or Torchlight.

3, 2015
												Unlike some "free to play" games here on Steam this one is actually 100% free. The game is huge and using real money on microtransactions offers no gameplay advantages. No pay-2-not-grind ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t here. This alone makes Path of Exile worth checking out.Rise, why are you giving this game a negative review then? Excellent question. To start with, the game took five minutes to start up every time. My friend's game took around 2-3 minutes and his PC is top notch. So you're looking at very high startup times unless you're running an SSD. Also, changing graphic settings might freeze or crash the game. This happened when trying to use windowed fullscreen or turning anti-aliasing on. I ended up having to play just plaing old windowed mode. High startup times are a problem for this type of game.The game itself is like Diablo 2 on shrooms. The combat felt slow and unresponsive, and the animations were clunky. Not something you'd expect from an Action RPG. The enemies are your classic goatmen, skellingtons, zombies and swarmy bugs. Sometimes the enemies are rare or unique. Even The Butcher made an appearance (only he was called Brutus but I know he was The Butcher), The setting is grimdark, as it should be.By the way, the graphics are amazing. Makes you wanna kill Blizzard for selling that PoS D3+expansion for 80 euros still.Now about that passive skill tree. One look at that tree and you know if you're staying or not. There is no way to know what passives are useful, no way to fully respec and I seriously doubt anyone truly knows whats going on with that skill tree. Like, come on people. There is no need to have something like that. Give me a few straight lines and I work it out from there.Overall not a very rousing experience. Check it out though since its free.

content:
24, 2016
												In a world where free titles either A) try to force you into microtransactions to win, or B) just plain suck, Path of Exile breaks the mold and is, well, neither. Every aspect of this game is polished. With the exception of some sporadic server issues, I can't find much of anything to dislike about this ARPG. You've got the whole package: highly customizable (and good) graphics, good OST for that dark ambience, tons of voice acting that isn't cheesy, online play (though it's required of course), and really fun skill customization. Think Final Fantasy 7's materia system (the skill orbs you put on your gear) and Final Fantasy 10's skill tree system (a huge web of connected orbs that give you a clear route as to what playstyle you want to go with). As for microtransactions, your instinct probably tells you this could potentially be pay-to-win. But fear not! All of the items purchased from the shop are purely cosmetic (with the exception of extra bank and character slots for those REALLY hardcore players). To me, this says the developers are confident that you might support them in the future for making such a killer game and just giving it away.Overall, PoE takes a fresh spin on a tired genre and gives it to you for free. If nothing else, just download this and keep it for a rainy day when you wanna scratch that ARPG itch.

er 5, 2016
												An amazing ARPG with great developers who are passionate about the game. At first the game will likely feel a bit overwhelming with the enormous skill tree and endless options for builds and skills to use. My advice for first time players is to just play and make up a build as you go, don't overthink it at first.If you like Diablo 2 then you owe it to yourself to give this a try, it's free to play. The game is monetized by players paying for cosmetics and extra storage space for items beyond the generous space you get for free, no devious methods of separating players from their money as you see in so many other free to play games.

												Path of Exile (PoE) is a great ARPG.It's complexity can be overwelming for beginners, but there are a lot of guides on the official forums that can point you into the right direction.The big thing that comes with complexity is variety - there are a lot of different skills that can be played in many different ways. Exploring these options is part of the fun.And it all comes as a Free to Play game, but I have to admit the (completely optional) microtransactions, like more stash space, can give you a slight edge.But then again if one sinks countless hours into the game, one could argue that buying some microtransactions to support the Devs is a fair thing to do.All in all - awsome game. 10/10

content:
7, 2015
												+ Art style fits "dark" and "realistic" theme perfectly.+ Graphics are also technically great without performance issues.+ Huge passive skill tree which leads to unlimited different playstyle.+ Gem based skill system allows you to try different setups anytime you want.+ Combat is not much different from other ARPG's but it works. Damage/HP/Mana balance is pretty good.+ Level design is OK. Game lenght is nice for players who seek a good campaign.+ And the best; everything above is completely free. Not a single balance-destroying microtransaction. So there is almost nothing to complain.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2015
												Close your eyes and go back to the year 2000 and remember the amazing times you had in Diablo 2 and open your eyes and wake back up in a beautiful modern take on that gritty ARPG you once loved.Path of Exile offers an incredible amount of flexibility the skill tree overwhelms many at first glance but once you tame that beast the freedom it gives you is unparalleled, it will honestly ruin all other ARPG's for you making you feel claustrophobic and want to escape back to the freedom that PoE gives you.Most communities are pretty toxic online and you might presume this to be the same but crack that hard outer shell and most people are willing to take the time to discuss their builds give you advice if you are stuck and sometimes even give you a hand killing a boss you are stuck/scared to take on or even give you some gear to help you move on.Not only does it crush all other ARPG's currently on the market it keeps evolving as well.The developers respond minutes within issues with the servers and listen to the community (not just the ones that whine the most), they consistently update the "meta" and have always tried to push the boundaries with adding various mechanics and adding new content whether it is new unique weapons or fresh mechanics and bosses.It's a game I've thoroughly enjoyed investing over 1000 hours into and I'm sure I will continue to invest 1000's more.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 25, 2016
												Path of Exile is a very deep ARPG with a rather unusual currency mechanic and a massive skill tree. It has a steep learning curve and can be somewhat punishing, but that's also what makes winning feel so rewarding.The devs have kept their promise of making the game truly free. Most microtransactions confer cosmetic changes. The only microtransaction that actually affects gameplay is unlocking additional stash tabs (bank storage space). I found that when I only had one character, it was pretty easy to stay within the limits of the default 4 tabs. After a hundred hours of gameplay, I felt like a small payment to be able to hoard more items was more than justifiable (and a bit more to make my new character look super cool!).The game is also kept interesting by regular challenge leagues where you start a new character in a separate game world with a fresh economy and different gameplay rules. At a low low price of free, it's definitely worth a go!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2016
												In a world where free titles either A) try to force you into microtransactions to win, or B) just plain suck, Path of Exile breaks the mold and is, well, neither. Every aspect of this game is polished. With the exception of some sporadic server issues, I can't find much of anything to dislike about this ARPG. You've got the whole package: highly customizable (and good) graphics, good OST for that dark ambience, tons of voice acting that isn't cheesy, online play (though it's required of course), and really fun skill customization. Think Final Fantasy 7's materia system (the skill orbs you put on your gear) and Final Fantasy 10's skill tree system (a huge web of connected orbs that give you a clear route as to what playstyle you want to go with). As for microtransactions, your instinct probably tells you this could potentially be pay-to-win. But fear not! All of the items purchased from the shop are purely cosmetic (with the exception of extra bank and character slots for those REALLY hardcore players). To me, this says the developers are confident that you might support them in the future for making such a killer game and just giving it away.Overall, PoE takes a fresh spin on a tired genre and gives it to you for free. If nothing else, just download this and keep it for a rainy day when you wanna scratch that ARPG itch.

content:
19, 2015
												"Path of Exile is everything that Diablo 3 failed to produce on launch" is what I hear being said a lot.What I'd like you to know is that Path of Exile is it's own game, with it's own idea, and a solid planning stage. Because of the lack of a "standard" currency system such a gold, or coin, players have to be a more evolved breed to approach this game. With a constantly evolving roster of events such as races, seasons and leagues, Path of Exile is the kind of game you can be a bit bored with and come back to months later and feel like you're in a completley new product!Most of the microtransactions by which the game survives are completely reasonably priced. A few extra bag pages for your stash, a couple cosmetic upgrades so you feel outside the norm, totally worth putting a bit into the company to say thanks for making a real hit. Enjoy Path of Exile, it's worth the download.

content:
, 2016
												Path of Exile is a video game of the massively multiplayer RPG genre similar to Diablo 3 (in fact the game was basically designed as a response to what the developers didn't like about D3). It's free-to-play with lots of things for sale in an in-game marketplace.Let's look at the pros and cons.Pros:  Free-to-play Endless customization Cool monsters and environments Passive Skill Tree is Huge Very good atmosphere thanks to great soundtracksCons:  Sometimes it can be difficult to play solo (especially if you wanna kill boss) Absence of the option to compare equipped items with the items in shopsI definitely give it a thumbs up and if developers focus on shortcomings, they have a great game, here!﻿Overall rating:  9/10

												Path of Exile is definitely the highest point an ARPG can achieve , it has the build diversity, the difficulty that can make you go mad, the real end game that can be only achieved by really putting the time and hard work on your character, and so much more.GGG is a great company and a model to follow, the game has the best Free To Play model i have ever seen, with constant 3 month updates, nothing you can buy will make you better in the game which is a very important thing, no content needs to be bought which is an even more important thing in a game.The only bad thing i find that is important is, the game is hard to run on shity PC's (my PC is 10 years old  XD) but they have improved that aspect a lot recently and the other thing is the Microtransaction prices, i think for example instead of 50 points for 5$ it should be 80-100, but if they made it that way they must have their reasons.With all that said, the game is awesome and definitely the best ARPG and i'm not seeing anyone doing it better.

content:
er 27, 2016
												I already reviewed this game a year or two ago, saying how good it was. I started playing it again not too long ago, and decided to come back and give it a new review, in order to help keep reviews fresh and relevant.So now at the end of 2016, almost 2017, how is it holding up to the test of time?In my opinion this game is still the golden standard of how a free to play game should be run. While the game has microtransactions, the only things you can buy are cosmetic things to change how you look. There is absolutely nothing you can buy that would give you an unfair advantage over others, and there is absolutely nothing you need to buy in order to play the full game. You can play the whole game beginning to end, with every character, as many times as you like for free. There is no catch whatsoever.In terms of graphics. While graphics have come a long way in the last few years, and there are some amazing looking games out there, I still find the graphics in Path Of Exile to be more than satisfactory. The visuals are more than enough to make you feel alone and scared, as well as excited, safe, or in trouble. Leading to an immersive experience.The game has also seen significant imrpovements from what I can tell. I could be mistaken, or may have just forgotten, but there seems to be way more cool items and new loot in the game compared to before. There are also new town characters with side quests, that if you complete, allows you to buy cooler and cooler things the more you level up your relationship with them.Back in the day, the game had issues with connexion from time to time, but that too seems to have been improved, with the game playing much smoother. I have not noticed any lag so far. It could be down to there being less people playing, but I don't think that is the case because it still seems like loads of people are playing on a regular basis.The game is really good, a solid 10 out of 10 for me. If this game had launched on the first day for 60 bucks it would have been worth it, and even today I still think it is worth a good 50 to 60 bucks. Considering it is totally free, you really can't complain.All in all I would say the game is just as good as it used to be if not better.So, what can you actually do in the game?You play as an exile that has been just abandoned and left to die on a monster infested island. You then fight your way through the levels, until becoming a god-like all powerful warrior.The game has loads of powerful items to help make yourself even more powerful, as well as a skill tree that seems to offer almost infinite options on how you want to build your character.While the main missions are a little short, you can play them on many difficulties. Also the game has a very good set of end game missions, that make up for how short the main missions are.I would compare it to Diablo 2, or Titan Quest, it is one of those kinds of games, but more modern and comprehensive versions, with a few unique twists.well worth a look if you like magic, action, RPG, MMO, epic adventures, or any combination.

content:
er 26, 2013
												If you like ARPGs and loved Diablo 2, but didn't like Torchlight, then this would definitely satisfy your need for a D2 style game. All active skills are based on resocketable gems, making you're character build your own, and the passive talent system is very reminscent of the sphere grid/tree/maze in FFX, which gives you even more lattitude in determining how you want to create your character over the long run.Some downsides:- Online only. This will cause you to have desync issues so you'll get some moments where you or monsters will teleport.- Bit of a learning curve. content:
ry 5, 2015
												After spending a very large portion of the past 2 years of my life playing and thoroughly enjoying this game I thought I would write a little review on it.This game innovates the ARPG genre in so many ways while remaining true to the genre's roots. The passive and skill gem system provide considerable customization and drive to improve your character, the visuals while not always AAA standards are fantastic and really help set the mood for the dark forsaken continent of Wraeclast. I dont listen to the music often as I am typically on mumble with my guild, but the sound design is also fantastic, particularly the Scion character's voice acting, you can truly feel her passion/heartache at the right moments, the game's sound effect often clearly illustrate finer details of the game such as a pile of loot dropping, a unique item dropping or a critical strike. With the frequent free content patches and the microtransactions that at the very most increase convenience make you well aware that these developers have the hardcore gamer's best interests at heart while still making the game accessible to newer and more casual players by involving the community in such things as game/build guides as well as a few podcasts that help you keep updated on what new patches mean and how the game's meta is shifting. On top of that the game's streaming community are mostly very helpful and educational with each streamer giving you something to take away and apply to your own character, whether it be one of Ziggyd's beginner guides or Havoc616 and Mathil's  attempts to farm the endiest endgame content imaginable or even Willywonka/Helman/Raizqt for their unique content, there is always something to learn.If I had one complaint it would be that a few engine issues keep it from being perfect. oh, and there isnt enough time to do all the builds that I think up.Thank you Grinding Gear Games for giving me such an amazing experience to share with my friends all across the globe.

content:
2, 2014
												Although I'm no huge fan of hack'n'slash RPGs, PoE was the first game of this genre since long ago (since D2 I bet) which managed to keep me playing for longer than just a few hours. Sure, I played D3 through but rather forcing myself than with relish, and I absolutely agree with the opinion that PoE is a way better match for the Diablo franchise than D3 itself. At least, it features the right look & feel, proper dark atmoshere, tons of customizable loot, much more interesting character development, and last but not least - appropriate size and length. And on top of all that it's completely free! "Free to play" but not "pay to win", so you can enjoy it to the full without spending a single cent.The downsides? Yeah, they exist too, but I'd describe them to be minor and inessential. Permanent connection to the server in a single-player game (but that's commonplace nowadays), somewhat bad placement of waypoints across locations which eventually forces you to replay certain (quite large) locations twice or even more times, rather sophisticated skill tree (not necessarily a bad thing). But the rich core gameplay pays it all off, I must say.In any case, I strongly recommend this brilliant game to all RPG fans and to anyone who loves good games no matter what genre they are. Despite some minor flaws, it is fully capable to carry you off the reality for some considerable time and give you bright and memorable experiences.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2016
												This is one of the best games ever made, and when played on hardcore it is one of the most difficult, challenging and rewarding games of the modern era, a triumph over most games of this generation, and a callback to times when every player had to learn the game they were playing in order to succeed, rather than being catered to and handheld. Except this time you have an interactive community to help you along the way, as the game features trading, partying, player housing, and an 'interesting' global chat. And what a journey it will be, the atmosphere of this game feels like a blend of Dark Souls meets Diablo. Despite the graphics being pretty simple there's a ton of heart and fantastic art direction+flavour paving every step of the way. There's literally thousands upon thousands of ways to build your character. (Despite this 90%* of the community just plays CoC builds) *hyperboleThe best part? The game is free, aside from some purely aesthetic microtransactions which look very nice. No pay2win here. (Until you need more stash tabs i.e storage space) The community is one of the most diverse (for better & for worse) communities I've ever encountered, and the depth of this game is greater than most MMORPG's, despite this genre being an online ARPG. The difficulty scales to an absurd extent, you can never truly "Faceroll" every aspect of this game,(Unless you play CoC, in which case please uninstall--you're not a good player, stop uploading twinned boss map clear videos to Reddit, nobody cares--except for other CoC players) and there's just so much depth and replayable value to this game that I really can't recommend it enough. The endgame, on hardcore, is insanely fun and often times heartracing, with immense risk and reward being omnipresent throughout the experience. The more you play this game, the more you want to play it, and that is a surefire sign of both an addictive problem and a masterpiece. On the negative side of things, the early portion of this game is a total, unintuitive mess--if you're unfamiliar with the ARPG genre, or even if you're somewhat familiar with it, the game will likely feel far too overwhelming to bother with, it doesn't even bother trying to tutorialize you, and while the exploratory independence the game gives you is ultimately empowering, it's a little too vacuous for genuinely new players. Several of the game's mechanics & character features are amazingly in depth and customizable once you begin to grasp them, but unfortunately they also come off as very hard to understand initially, and even once you begin to understand them you'll likely fail to fully realize what you can do with them for quite some time. None of this is necessarily "bad", but it could certainly be offputting to a large demographic. The pace of the game is also painfully slow early on, this is especially true if you have no gear and if you're new to the game-most new players and even several veteran players don't know how to level efficiently, and waste a lot of excess time doing certain pointless side quests, picking up every useless item, killing every mob, doing irrelevant side areas, etc. Bluntly put, combat will not feel satisfying for a while, but when your build starts to come together and the enemies start to possess actually significant mechanics, boy oh boy does the world ever turn upside down. On top of that, the "true" game doesn't kick off until merciless difficulty, by which point you'll already have "beaten the campaign" twice, and this is presently very unintuitive to newer players, so a significant portion of the "playerbase" ends up "beating" the game (in their eyes) on normal and then never returning, even though the real experience hasn't even begun yet (Although regardless, at least these people get to experience the boss fight "Malachai", which is something you'll probably not soon forget). However, I'd still implore anyone who might turn away from the game because of these reasons to *just trudge through it* because, come merciless difficulty, come MAPS, it'll all prove to be deeply worth it. Once you get your first good unique item, once you 5 link or 6 link your first item, etc. etc., you'll have nowhere to go but up. That is, until your character dies and you angrily uninstall or reroll a CoC build. Screw CoC builds they're killing the game and trivializing the content, alright GGG you caught me this was all really an elaborate ruse with the actual intent of this review being nothing more than a rant about CoC builds. CoC builds are utterly faceroll and negate all strategic thought, difficulty, mechanics, and build variety involved in this game. Also nerf lightning coil and blade vortex. GOTY.

												Holy crap this game is addictive. If you like anything about the Diablo series, this is the game for you. While it is free to play and has microtransactions for support, most of them are only for cosmetic and convienience items. You can pick up silly stuff like visual effects for your weapons and footprints or even a pet to follow you around. The only really beneficial purchases I found were inventory expansions that would probably be boderline necessary in the later game. Speaking of late game, be prepared to dedicate a lot of time to grinding and exploring before you are anywhere near leveled up or powerful. While its farly easy to outpace the starting areas, the game has a ton of content and it wil take a huge ammount of time to level up a single character to 80. And while we are forwarning, its also not one of those hold your hand and guide you through everything kind of games. It will giive you general directions and show you the basics of controls then you are on your own. Want to know how a spell or weapon works? Read the detail screens then put it on and try it out. There is no real explination to anything aside form short decriptive texts on items and abilities. Be prepared to work to learn this game, while its not as brutal as Dark Souls, it will not hold your hand and tell you when to hit "A".Overall, this is a fantastic game but will devour your free time if you let it. I've had to cut back recently because I know that if I start a game I will feel the need to continue for hours before I find a reasonable stopping point. Absolutly worth the time though, so go try it.

content:
r 23, 2013
												Fantastically done aRPG. Don't let the fact that it's free disuade you from playing it. The love and attention to detail GGG has put into this game clearly shines through. If you ever loved a diablo or torchlight game, do yourself a favor and start playing PoE!+3 years after first review:The devs have continued to improve upon and expand this game since release. Roughly 4 challenge leagues occur a year with game play mechanics from these leagues sometimes making their way into core game (Essences are the latest mechanic to be rolled into core) make for a fairly interesting shelf life for this aRPG. They just recently released their revamp of end-game content and are in the process of changing the entire game engine to reflect current day technology. GGG's community managers are highly active on reddit and PoE forums, their customer service is one of the easiest and honestly nicest group of people you could ever deal with, and as a company GGG continually listens to their playerbase and is rather transparent. In regards to gameplay: the one "downfall" of this game is that there is almost no hand-holding and most of the mechanics are left for you to discover instead of explained in game. In my experience, it wasn't until I hit roughly 30 hours of playtime that I broke into the second difficulty level. However, it is a game that is rewarding and through wiki and chat help, it is very possible to uncover the innards of the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
15, 2015
												Path of Exile is the most faithful successor to Diablo 2 that you'll find, including Diablo 3. While D3 took the approach of World of Warcraft's evolution, focusing on becoming more streamlined and more accessible than its predecessor, Path of Exile leans in the opposite direction. It's difficult, it's technical, and it's awesome. Truly, if feels as if everything that Diablo 3 did wrong, Path of Exile does right.The one area that PoE really diverges from the classic Diablo formula is in the active skill system. Active skills are granted by gem items. Skill gems gain experience and level up independantly of your character, and by combining active skill gems with "support gems" in equipment with appropriately-linked sockets, the combinations are vast.And that's what's really great about this game. The enormous scope of build variety and character customization. PoE's passive skill tree has hundreds and hundreds of nodes, and over the course of your character's career you'll have over 100 passive skill points to allocate in any direction and combination you see fit. Want to build a huge, muscle-bound Marauder that casts spells and holds wands? Want to create a Witch or Ranger that uses a Cyclone melee attack with a two-handed axe? Go for it. If you enjoy theorycrafting, you're bound to love this game.It's the most technical hack-and-slash ARPG out there, and likely the most unforgiving. The path to 100 is a long, long road, and once you're on the second and third difficulties you'll start losing experience with each death. It might get frustrating, but this is not a bad thing. The challenge and longevity this game presents is a breath of fresh air.And, somehow, the game is entirely free. There is -zero- "pay to win" here. You can buy extra stash tabs (though it's not at all necessary, they start you with four for free), but all the rest of the offered microtransactions are for purely cosmetic items. There is no way to get any sort of in-game boost or mechanical advantage by spending money.As a huge fan of the genre, PoE really feels like the most compelling offering as of right now.

												This game will eat your life.I love and hate this game at the same time. It is starting to get dated, but new players will find so much to do that they won't even notice.The game has settled into two basic groups. 1) The 500+ hour player who is still struggles to make a character that is viable for end game content and 2) the 2000+ hour gamers who know every explot in the game and post videos on youtube about it.  Both groups still seem to have fun.The game has a steep learning curve for an AARPG, but can still be played with just basic understanding.  The most overwhelming thing is the skill tree. You will certainly mess up your first few characters, but that is part of the fun.It is the closest toa truly "free-to-play" game I've ever seen of its quality. The only real $ transactions are for asthetics and extra storage.  As long as you're not a pack rat, you never have to spend a dime. However, if you find that you put in 100+ hours on the game, you won't feel too bad dropping a little cash for storage and the money sorting system.Get it, play it, hate it, love it.

content:
er 25, 2013
												It's everything you wanted in Diablo 3 and more. The passive skill tree is awe inspiring the first time you see it. It's more like a skill forest. The sheer volume of content in this game is incredible. The character customization and build diversity is quite extensive. There are so many different ways to play and new things are still being discovered daily. The game is 100% free. Now I know what you're thinking, "Whats the catch?" Thats just it, there isn't one. The only items you can buy in this game are purely cosmetic. There is no pay to win. The only thing that remotely comes close to being "p2w" is spending money on stash space. The Devs are INCREDIBLE and actively engage the player base via in game global chat, forums and even sites like reddit. (www.reddit.com/r/pathofexile). They are constantly improving and adding new content. It seems there is a new expansion twice every year, and every three months there is a new mechanic introduced in the form of a three month temporary league where everyone starts over to complete a designated set of challenges for cosmetic items. They just added 64bit support and multicore support. They have already handled rubberbanding or "desync" in the form of a new mode called "lockstep" with assurances that more quality of life AND content are on the way.It's free, so what do you have to lose?...except your social life of course. Welcome to Wraeclast, exile.

er 23, 2016
												The best ARPG by a longshot. Insane character-customization, huge amount of stuff to do, high difficulty, high learning curve, but extremely satisfactory when you pull off your own build after huge amount of theorycrafting and see it unfold into an absolute powerhouse.Everyone that is bored of other ARPG's should try out this game. Just as a hint though. Do not get fooled by the slowness of its early game. The game gets MUCH faster later on. Try to stick withit until you reach maps, thats where the true endgame really begins.Another awesome part of this game: frequent content updates and balancing patches. Every 3 months comes a content patch with a new challenge league (basically like a new season in other ARPG's) with these new challenge leagues comes  a new piece of content (new items, new bossfights, etc.). Some content patches are catered towards early game, some are catered towards endgame, some revamp a huge part of the existing content ontop of adding new stuff (like a new act).Free to play model consists of mostly cosmetic microtransactions. The small part that is not cosmetic are additional stashtabs or upgrades to premium stashtabs (these can be renamed and recoloured for more customization and visibility). The only downside to this game is the CURRENT form of its trading system (which they already said they are reworking).

												A Diablo style game that seems to have made a ton of fun design decisions. I vote it best in class. There are many game varieties and I recommend that everyone race as often as you can (it's a game!). The achievements are challenging. No matter which level you are playing, something great could drop at any moment. A TON of character build variety. You can find a basic item and turn it into an incredibly better item with innovative game currency (and relatively cheaply). Easy to group when you are in the mood. The game is frequently updated and the developers are active in the community. Truly Free to Play. Support is responsive.The in-game armor and weapon visual effects that you can buy are more expensive than I would like (30ish dollars US in some cases).update: I deleted the bit about lag being a problem. If you have good internet then the newly added lock-step improvements make the gameplay super smooth and responsive. So many great changes with the recenly released version 2.0 (The Awakening). One of the few companies that is continually giving the community what they request.

ber 8, 2016
												10/10This is the diablo-like with the most depth and design complexity I've ever played. There's so much character development possibilities, the game is amazing at giving tools to create the most crazy and ambitious builds and to make it incredibly rewarding. From the gigantic passive tree, to the crazy combination of gems you can make or how certain unique items completely change how some skill works... It's so amazing at letting you be creative and come up with ways to grow your character! And then the world of wreaclast is just amazing to explore, lots of lore and a very grim and dark setting reminding of the best parts of diablo 1. The soundtrack is incredible as well.Hand down my favorite diablo like and one of my fave games of all time, and it's truly free (money only gives cosmetics and inventory management help). The few cons - you cant turn the camera, meaning its best to attack enemies from the south when you're a long range hero. -Self Founds will have a hard time progressing in the end game.- Act 2 is unfortunately pretty boring compared to the rest of the game.

												This game is a phenomenal example of Free to Play and Action RPGs done right. Non-intrusive microtransactions, all of the content in the game, sans cosmetic skins, is available for free. The game has an incredible amount of complexity and character customization, which is constantly getting better as the developers fine tune and iterate each patch / "mini-expansion".The only concern I've ever had was Desync, which depending on your character build, will either be negligible or a major problem to deal with. Desync essentially being a period of time where your client and the game server disagree on where you or monsters are, potentially resulting in sudden death as one or the other catches up, only for you to realize that the clear field you thought you were in is actually full of deadly face-eating skeletons.

content:
y 10, 2016
												I thought this game deserved a further review considering the hours I tanked into it recently.(My original review is still at the bottom)Path of Exile is amazing, comparing it to diablo dosen't do it any justice, it's an ARPG and borrows some fundementals set by the old style games, but gives you so much more to work with. When you start the game you choose a class (starting place on the talent tree) and you are dumped on a beach, and you go from there. What skills you use, what gear you wear, however you want to roleplay is upto the player.\PoE has near infinite hours of replayability, new builds, challenge leagues, races and PVP, freedom is the name of the game. It's open.If you like the sound of creating a build from the huge range of options or like deleting hoards of goatmen, or want to spend all day trading, or want to measure your e-peen on one of the ladders. PoE has something that'll hook you.GGG, to me, seem like one of the best games developers I've seen, and they do a tremendous job bringing new content to the player-base... for free! Microtransactions are free, there are no pay-to-win features at all, cosmetics and storage space are most of what you can find. It's refreshing to see microtransations not being shoved down your throat, they are expensive enough that they are not all that common, but still affordable, while making the game profitable for GGG.=======================================================================I dont use the steam client because the official one is more my style. (Thats why it says I only have 11 hours)Great ARPG. So many ways to play this game. Can't recommend it enough if you are looking for a timekiller that dosent require too much effort.It's also has a very fair free-to-play model, based off buying storage space, character slots and cosmetics, all the people complaining about having to get more storage etc, should take a look at how much goes into this game, and consider the price-tag.

r 24, 2013
												If you have any bias towards free to play games this one is an example of how they should be done, there is literally no pay to win (unless you rwt which will get you banned) and almost all of the pay for items are cosmetic apart from the extra stash tabs which you will only need if you are a hoarder or endgame. Like i said in my torchlight 2 review if you liked diablo 2 then give this a shot, be warned though it will consume your life. To simplify the gameplay to a great degree, the drops are all randomised with the exception of the uniques which also have variable values for the bonuses they provide, and the skill system is gem based and is a lot like the materia system from final fantasy 7. You can link certain gems together to get them to combine the effects and that is pretty much what your build will be based around and how you deal damage. Endgame you can either start a new build, start a hardcore character, do maps or start doing the races and other things they schedule.Tl:Dr  i like it

												TL;DR sum-up of PoE:  FTP Diablo 2.PoE is a FTP Diablo 2 knock off and I mean that in the most lovingly way possible.  Honestly, I'm surprised Blizzard hasn't gone after their asses.  From the character choices, graphics, minions (goat-men!!), hell, even the music, anyone who has played D2 will know immediately what I'm talking about. I, like many others, was crushed by what D3 turned into.  Looking for what D3 should have been?  Here's your answer.Is it really FTP?  yes.  The only, and I mean ONLY, things you can buy are cosmetic enhancements. Yay, glowing swords....Did I tell you there are almost daily competitions and races?  Well there are.  Examples:    Who can run the fastest through the game only using melee?  Oh you're a witch?  Well, better get swinging!    Unique dungeon crawls where you can't go home and fix your boo-boos or buy better equipment.  Use what you find, son!And don't worry, the playing field is leveled for this:  to do a race you must start with a brand new character.  Only your wits will help you prevail!  ...And lucky loot drops.I recommend this game, and for those nostalgic for D2; the first goat-bleat will warm your soul.  Happy left-button smashing!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
15, 2015
												Path of Exile is the most faithful successor to Diablo 2 that you'll find, including Diablo 3. While D3 took the approach of World of Warcraft's evolution, focusing on becoming more streamlined and more accessible than its predecessor, Path of Exile leans in the opposite direction. It's difficult, it's technical, and it's awesome. Truly, if feels as if everything that Diablo 3 did wrong, Path of Exile does right.The one area that PoE really diverges from the classic Diablo formula is in the active skill system. Active skills are granted by gem items. Skill gems gain experience and level up independantly of your character, and by combining active skill gems with "support gems" in equipment with appropriately-linked sockets, the combinations are vast.And that's what's really great about this game. The enormous scope of build variety and character customization. PoE's passive skill tree has hundreds and hundreds of nodes, and over the course of your character's career you'll have over 100 passive skill points to allocate in any direction and combination you see fit. Want to build a huge, muscle-bound Marauder that casts spells and holds wands? Want to create a Witch or Ranger that uses a Cyclone melee attack with a two-handed axe? Go for it. If you enjoy theorycrafting, you're bound to love this game.It's the most technical hack-and-slash ARPG out there, and likely the most unforgiving. The path to 100 is a long, long road, and once you're on the second and third difficulties you'll start losing experience with each death. It might get frustrating, but this is not a bad thing. The challenge and longevity this game presents is a breath of fresh air.And, somehow, the game is entirely free. There is -zero- "pay to win" here. You can buy extra stash tabs (though it's not at all necessary, they start you with four for free), but all the rest of the offered microtransactions are for purely cosmetic items. There is no way to get any sort of in-game boost or mechanical advantage by spending money.As a huge fan of the genre, PoE really feels like the most compelling offering as of right now.

er 23, 2016
												The best ARPG by a longshot. Insane character-customization, huge amount of stuff to do, high difficulty, high learning curve, but extremely satisfactory when you pull off your own build after huge amount of theorycrafting and see it unfold into an absolute powerhouse.Everyone that is bored of other ARPG's should try out this game. Just as a hint though. Do not get fooled by the slowness of its early game. The game gets MUCH faster later on. Try to stick withit until you reach maps, thats where the true endgame really begins.Another awesome part of this game: frequent content updates and balancing patches. Every 3 months comes a content patch with a new challenge league (basically like a new season in other ARPG's) with these new challenge leagues comes  a new piece of content (new items, new bossfights, etc.). Some content patches are catered towards early game, some are catered towards endgame, some revamp a huge part of the existing content ontop of adding new stuff (like a new act).Free to play model consists of mostly cosmetic microtransactions. The small part that is not cosmetic are additional stashtabs or upgrades to premium stashtabs (these can be renamed and recoloured for more customization and visibility). The only downside to this game is the CURRENT form of its trading system (which they already said they are reworking).

content:
er 25, 2013
												It's everything you wanted in Diablo 3 and more. The passive skill tree is awe inspiring the first time you see it. It's more like a skill forest. The sheer volume of content in this game is incredible. The character customization and build diversity is quite extensive. There are so many different ways to play and new things are still being discovered daily. The game is 100% free. Now I know what you're thinking, "Whats the catch?" Thats just it, there isn't one. The only items you can buy in this game are purely cosmetic. There is no pay to win. The only thing that remotely comes close to being "p2w" is spending money on stash space. The Devs are INCREDIBLE and actively engage the player base via in game global chat, forums and even sites like reddit. (www.reddit.com/r/pathofexile). They are constantly improving and adding new content. It seems there is a new expansion twice every year, and every three months there is a new mechanic introduced in the form of a three month temporary league where everyone starts over to complete a designated set of challenges for cosmetic items. They just added 64bit support and multicore support. They have already handled rubberbanding or "desync" in the form of a new mode called "lockstep" with assurances that more quality of life AND content are on the way.It's free, so what do you have to lose?...except your social life of course. Welcome to Wraeclast, exile.

r 24, 2013
												If you have any bias towards free to play games this one is an example of how they should be done, there is literally no pay to win (unless you rwt which will get you banned) and almost all of the pay for items are cosmetic apart from the extra stash tabs which you will only need if you are a hoarder or endgame. Like i said in my torchlight 2 review if you liked diablo 2 then give this a shot, be warned though it will consume your life. To simplify the gameplay to a great degree, the drops are all randomised with the exception of the uniques which also have variable values for the bonuses they provide, and the skill system is gem based and is a lot like the materia system from final fantasy 7. You can link certain gems together to get them to combine the effects and that is pretty much what your build will be based around and how you deal damage. Endgame you can either start a new build, start a hardcore character, do maps or start doing the races and other things they schedule.Tl:Dr  i like it

content:
r 30, 2013
												Path of Exile is a complex and engaging free to play action RPG set in the grim world of Wraeclast. The atmosphere is very dark and interesting. Players slowly uncover the secrets behind their exile and Wraeclast. The lore is scattered throughout the game world and really adds to the immersion.The passive tree is absolutely massive and extremely diverse, allowing for almost any playstyle imaginable. Skills can be augmented with "Support Gems" to significantly modify what they do and to create some truly outrageous combinations. The amazing unique items in the game only add to the already overwhelming amount of character customization. The result is a theorycrafter's wet dream. Another major feature is that there is no "gold" as a form of currency. Instead there are numerous items of varying rarity that modify almost every aspect of items you find. These currency items allow players to custom tailor their gear while simultaneously combating inflation of the economy since they are consumed on use.The game also features "Races", which are timed competitve events ranging from a few minutes to a couple hours. Races can have many additional features and restrictions to make them more fun and challenging. Some races are designed to be almost an entire different game mode than the base game. Races are separated by Seasons, allowing players to earn points and win limited time alternate art unique items.On top of all this, Grinding Gear Games is one of the most communicative developers I have ever experienced. They are very active in the community and take all suggestions and feedback seriously. Lastly, the game features a completely non pay to win microtransaction model. All game content is available right from the start. Real money will only buy you cosmetic effects to make your character look awesome and a few account features for convenience. I highly recommend trying out Path of Exile if you have even the slightest bit of interest in the genre.
