content:
r 28, 2013
												After not enjoying the Closed Beta and early Open Beta (after climbing to level 36, and 29 in each) I decided that the game was sluggish and "Not For Me" while admiring the dark Diablo 1 and Diablo 2 style Art Design and attempted feel, along with the best ARPG graphic engine and shadows to be displayed in a ARPG title yet.Luckily GGC has been able to pull off an amazing development cycle since that point, I read up on it finally being released after 7 years &decided to give it another shot! I am glad I did, as all issues I had with the game are not only fixed, but changed in a way that feels perfect in all aspects - I do not see any area that they could have improved on further from the point I started playing at to the release; with that in mind some of these aspeccts and more will be altered further making the title even better. After only 22 levels as a Shadow going for a unique twist on the Dual Spike Armor/HP/Regen/HealthMana Leeching builds out there (I allocated 75 points that I thought seemed perfect; 85  "In case I grind that much out" 100 as "Pipe Dream Build" The developers stated that Magic The Gathering was the main inspiration for the Skill Web allowing any class to "Break the Rules" tactically and come up with their own vision of a build that developers may not have assumed would "Work" as cited by GGC for MTG how endless players such as I made decks in the standard rotation that nobody thought of doing as it seemed unconventional; every tournament and magic event I went to with my most recent deck right prior to Theros being released shook my hand even if I took the loss of the set stating "Thats the most interesting" or "That is one of the most amazing decks I've seen" "or Played against" - Nothing feels better than building ideas on your own with a vision of HOW it should be executed.PoE allows this My shadow is going to turn many heads and just as I "Broke" the way "WoW's Burning Crusade" end game worked (as stated by Mod on a Forum Post) by allocating a skill tree never displayed prior online (or until 3-4 months of using it, then I personally posted it so other Hunters could try it) along with a Mixture of PVP Arena Gear and Raid gear to keep the #1 DPS spot in Raids; while without switching abilities or gear be top of any battleground Leaderboard with (for example 24 Kills, 11 assists and 3 deaths.) - With that mindset...PoE allows you to not have to depend on just gear or just a build ; aside from the endless web of skills and attribute boosts that makes FFX look like Diablo 3 in "Scope, Scale and Staggering Size" The gems being socketed into gear that you alter with interconnecting slots to have multiple abilities chained with multiple support (such as three elements per Double Strike or Multi-strike with a Crit Damage Support Gem alongside the Double Strike (depending on how the sockets are connected)  New Players will feel at home but may need to check how the skill trees differentiate or do not differentiate each class. Along with how a Common item drop may end up being one of the most devestating pieces of gear you find depending on how you alter it after using an unhealthy amount of Armor or Weapon Quality Upgrades; which then allows the Gem Socket change gem to have higher % chance of adding more sockets (I was able to get a 5 socketed claw at level 22 due to this method upgraded to yellow; with stats that are mind blowing). It shows that the user is really in control.I cannot reccommend this game enough giving it an honest solid 9.1/10 *my rating scale is very very "this game needs to be perfect to be perfect* as seeon my IGN profile reviews for each title I own. - I deducted .1 points due to a rather insane 9 dollars per card drop for steam cards or else it would be a 9.2; if it was 9 dollars to initiate all card drops the score would remain the same.That's a solid 9.1/10 PLAY IT. NOW.

content:
10, 2014
												Might just be the best F2P game I've ever played. Looks gorgeous, sounds pleasantly, runs smoothly, feels very good to play. There is certainly a cathartic "oomph" to the combat and the killing. Also, the F2P model is possibly the most honorable. The only items sold are cosmetics and stash storage space -- they're not cheap, but they don't impact the game.There's a choice of 6 classes, which are presented to you much in the style of ol' Diablo 2: Templar, Shadow, Marauder, Ranger, Duelist and Witch. Unlike the old game, however, each class is very maleable and inter-changeable, in both passive skills and active abilities. The latter come in the form of gems, colour-code in regards to which attribute they adher to: green for Dexterity, red for Strength and blue for Intelligence.Each class has 2 initial direct paths of skills. A ranger, for instance, can choose to excel with bows, at range, or go the path of duel-wielding in melee combat. And at later stages, new, farther branches of passive skills are available to customize your character with, allowing you to mold your character's combat aptitude in detail.This might seem complex at first, but do not be drawn away, it's really quite simple and easy to map out.Lastly, I've noted nothing in the ways of bugs, glitches or significant imbalances.Heartily reccommended to any Diablo player!

The community is mostly very nice. Immature (not young-age has nothing to do with it) or cocky players tend to quit, cause the learning treshold is quite high. Be nice ingame, and you will get all the help you need. Global chat can be a way to meet other players (or get trolled if you are unlucky), or just throw in some questions if you trade.To summarise: PoE is a game that never gets old. Frustrating as hell sometimes, for sure, but never boring.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 22, 2014
												Path of Exile is undoubtedly one of the best free-to-play titles in recent years. If you're a fan of eerie & spine chilling, fantasy hack 'n' slash games where fighting huge mobs of ghastly creatures and ominous soldiers are the norm, Path of Exile is for you. As many have said already, this game has a very similar feel to the Diablo series and takes a large amount of influence from it (i.e. how the game is set into Acts and once you have completed them you can move onto harder difficulties), but also adds something of it's own into the mix such as having no currency in the game. Path of Exile is what Diablo 3 should have been and totally takes the cake between the two. The amount of content in the game is astounding and sometimes I can't believe that this game is free-to-play. Of course, you have your proverbial microtransactions but unlike other games, Path of Exile offers mostly non-competitive items for sale such as more character slots and guild options. Player vs. Player is another great element to the game and from what I have seen it contains 1 vs 1, 3 vs 3 and 6 vs 6 arenas though the matchmaking is a bit buggy when joining a queue. So, if you are looking for an overly addicting, loot driven, online hack 'n' slash game with tons of gore and brutality, download this game now! You won't regret it!

content:
r 28, 2013
												After not enjoying the Closed Beta and early Open Beta (after climbing to level 36, and 29 in each) I decided that the game was sluggish and "Not For Me" while admiring the dark Diablo 1 and Diablo 2 style Art Design and attempted feel, along with the best ARPG graphic engine and shadows to be displayed in a ARPG title yet.Luckily GGC has been able to pull off an amazing development cycle since that point, I read up on it finally being released after 7 years &decided to give it another shot! I am glad I did, as all issues I had with the game are not only fixed, but changed in a way that feels perfect in all aspects - I do not see any area that they could have improved on further from the point I started playing at to the release; with that in mind some of these aspeccts and more will be altered further making the title even better. After only 22 levels as a Shadow going for a unique twist on the Dual Spike Armor/HP/Regen/HealthMana Leeching builds out there (I allocated 75 points that I thought seemed perfect; 85  "In case I grind that much out" 100 as "Pipe Dream Build" The developers stated that Magic The Gathering was the main inspiration for the Skill Web allowing any class to "Break the Rules" tactically and come up with their own vision of a build that developers may not have assumed would "Work" as cited by GGC for MTG how endless players such as I made decks in the standard rotation that nobody thought of doing as it seemed unconventional; every tournament and magic event I went to with my most recent deck right prior to Theros being released shook my hand even if I took the loss of the set stating "Thats the most interesting" or "That is one of the most amazing decks I've seen" "or Played against" - Nothing feels better than building ideas on your own with a vision of HOW it should be executed.PoE allows this My shadow is going to turn many heads and just as I "Broke" the way "WoW's Burning Crusade" end game worked (as stated by Mod on a Forum Post) by allocating a skill tree never displayed prior online (or until 3-4 months of using it, then I personally posted it so other Hunters could try it) along with a Mixture of PVP Arena Gear and Raid gear to keep the #1 DPS spot in Raids; while without switching abilities or gear be top of any battleground Leaderboard with (for example 24 Kills, 11 assists and 3 deaths.) - With that mindset...PoE allows you to not have to depend on just gear or just a build ; aside from the endless web of skills and attribute boosts that makes FFX look like Diablo 3 in "Scope, Scale and Staggering Size" The gems being socketed into gear that you alter with interconnecting slots to have multiple abilities chained with multiple support (such as three elements per Double Strike or Multi-strike with a Crit Damage Support Gem alongside the Double Strike (depending on how the sockets are connected)  New Players will feel at home but may need to check how the skill trees differentiate or do not differentiate each class. Along with how a Common item drop may end up being one of the most devestating pieces of gear you find depending on how you alter it after using an unhealthy amount of Armor or Weapon Quality Upgrades; which then allows the Gem Socket change gem to have higher % chance of adding more sockets (I was able to get a 5 socketed claw at level 22 due to this method upgraded to yellow; with stats that are mind blowing). It shows that the user is really in control.I cannot reccommend this game enough giving it an honest solid 9.1/10 *my rating scale is very very "this game needs to be perfect to be perfect* as seeon my IGN profile reviews for each title I own. - I deducted .1 points due to a rather insane 9 dollars per card drop for steam cards or else it would be a 9.2; if it was 9 dollars to initiate all card drops the score would remain the same.That's a solid 9.1/10 PLAY IT. NOW.

content:
y 19, 2014
												Path of Exile is worthy of any action-RPG's fan's attention - especially since the game is free.  If one wishes to support the game developers, money can be spent for cosmetic changes and to increase your stash size, but neither are required to play the game.While the passive skill tree is enormous, it does require a bit of thought and planning to be utilized effectively.  Active skills are socketed to items, allowing unique combinations and a large amount of variety to gameplay (although, some options are far more effective than others).  Skills are leveled through experience that your character gains as they are socketed in an equipped item.Disadvantages...two in my experience: descynchronization from the required servers, even with ample internet capability; the targeting system is frustrating for melee type characters.  Both are irritating and exacerbate each other, often leading to character deaths.  As with Diablo 3 (the only other ARPG game that I have played with a server connection requirement), this has kept me from playing hardcore characters.  It's a shame, because I enjoy the challenge.Overall, I will wholeheartedly recommend the game, despite the above-mentioned flaws.  The developer seems committed and responsive to the fans / supporters, which is a nice bonus and will hopefully ensure future changes which allow for better, more reliable gameplay.  Additionally, the amount of variety and different gameplay options (races, ladder servers, etc.) should keep long term players' attention.

y 5, 2014
												(I am not native English speaker, but i will do my best)Would you like this game? If you dont like ARPG genre, then this will be waste of your time. But if you like slaying tons of monsters in order to get loot. If you are happy as a little child, when you find, or craft a good item. If you like sorting items, perfecting your character, preciselly craft him as a diamond (Your character once ugly stone, can became after signifficant effort a "diamond") When you dont mind spending lot of your time theorycrafting, then you can pick Path of Exile.Here, i just sumarize good and bad things about it, I played game since Open Beta and i have played more than 300 hours (outside of Steam)If you dont like reading, here is summary: Its a great game, but YOU need to come to it, game does not came to you easily (and you can also play with your friends, or established guild)Cons-Server lag, desync: This is bane of Path of Exile, but you need to build around it, or just have it in mind when playing. -No direct lore: You need to find lore and piece of story in game. But killing is more fun than reading text, there should be at least few cutscenes-Not friendly to new players, or newbies to this genre: Builds can really shine end or lategame, but player can be bored, and definitelly will be if he/she is unaware of this fact. I will personally add some stage, when game will give you endgame character to play with,for few minutes. Maybe in some intro part, before you find yourself lying in water, stranded on a beach.-Trading: Hard to get into, there is allready community made player shop indexers, but this feature shoud be integrated.-PVP: Well, it is hard to balance it.Pros-Sheer size of possibilities-Skill gem system: Passive tree is huge, but its not that complicated at all, but combining active skills and support skills into various combination is thing, that i like the most-Fair f2p system: Ok, stash tabs can be considered as pay2win element, but you can make new characters and store your loot  in their inventories.-Frequent patches and temporary leagues: Its good, that devs want to cooperate with community, and keep their game fresh.-End game: End game map system.

content:
er 17, 2014
												Easily the best game of the genre. Easily amongst the greatest F2P models. Easily the most deep and creative ways to build your character. Easily a must-play for everyone.Pros- FANTASTIC free to play model. You get the entire game right off the bat. There's really no 'except' or 'but' to this, you seriously just straight up get the entirety of the game. All the things you can spend $ on are things such as cosmetics for your character, pets, decorative set pieces for your hideout, and other petty stuff along those lines.- The game features perhaps the deepest way to create a character's build in video gaming history. You see, the game has a passives tree with over 1,000 nodes to invest in. The class you pick merely determines where in the tree you'll start. For example, The Duelist class starts on the bottom, where strength and dexterity meet.  Here is a picture [i.imgur.com] of the current passives tree. This massive tree combined with the strange way you mix skill gems with support gems to bend your spells to do exatecly what you want. For example, you can attach a fireball (skill gem) with Lesser Multiple Projectiles (a support gem). Now instead of 1 fireball, you now shoot 3. Or perhaps you want to summon a totem to shoot the fireballs for you? Or maybe your fireballs fork into two more fireballs when they hit an enemy. On top of that, "unique" items in the game can bend the normal rules for your character, to allow for even more creativity and possibilites present. - Three month leagues with special rules or permanent leagues. A multitude of various races to start a character at level 1 and reach the furthest in the game in a certain time under certain rules running every day. Softcore or hardcore. There's a lot of variety present in the game which is sure to find your niche.- Amazing developers deliver content on the regular. I took a break from the game (after about 1,200 hours) for 3 months and when I came back there were 14 new support gems, 7 new skills, a new master system, personal hideouts, and more bugfixes/quality of life changes than I cared to read in one session. Cons- *...cough...- JK, there is a learning curve. It may take you a few hours to get a real feel for the game. For people like me, that's actually a Pro, but may be a bit off putting to some.I give the game 10/10, and award it 'Best Indie Game', 'Best Crowdfunded Game', and 'Best ARPG'go play it u doofus

content:

												TL:DR – A fun, free, online, click, click, click RPG that’s light on story with enough things to do that will keep all but the most hardcore player interested (for a bit, at least).I’ll just start with the greatest selling point of Path of Exile—no selling point. Free helps as most of the flaws don’t seem quite so harsh at that price. You’ll click on wave after wave of bad guy as you roll the loot piñata dice in hopes that this time the Staff of Iwin drops. Path of Exile is a fun little game that you’ll find yourself loading up from time to time to kill a couple of waves of bad guys before your wrist starts to hurt. 7/10.The Good—Free: Only costs bandwidth and time to download.Characters: Lots of character classes.Items: Lots of stuffs with skills being placed on gem drops to make the game different. Grinding: Now with 10% less hamster wheel.Online Community: Friends need only apply. Leagues: Lots of different events and contests for frequent players.Updates: Fairly often with new expansions and drastic changes to gameplay to keep the game interesting.The Bad—Repetitive: You better like killing snakes in the forest zone, because you’ll do lots of it.Graphics: Not bad, but worse than the competition. Much worse.Online: People who are not your friend will annoy you. Greatly.In Game Purchases: Currently, this isn’t bad but things could easily be changed to bad and make the game not worth running.

er 1, 2015
												Imagine they stripped the drawn out story and fluff pieces from a Diablo title and made it all about the dungeon crawl.  Spells and abilities in this game are customizable in many more creative ways than Diablo ever had to offer, and I feel like there are always unique things to try out and discover.As for the biggest selling point, I'm incredibly fond of the league system in place.  There are many temporary leagues that span from a few minutes to multiple months.  This means that you can always find a brand new environment to start playing in and not feel punished for being months behind other players like one continuous world would.With that said, I'd warn against picking this game up if you have a midterm or finals week approaching within the next month.

												Levo jugando desde el inicio de la beta (Febrero) y para mí es el mejor indie del año y el MMORPG de la decada. Es lo que Diablo 3 tenía que haber sido, los pequeños detallles, la cantidad de magias equilibradas, un PvP nivelado, y un high-end de lo más variado. 20 personas (ahora 33) owned Bizzard. Es una mezcla de grandes juegos (FFVII, FFX, Titanquest, Diablo 2, Neverwinter... más unas cuantas ideas propias (un árbol de +1000 pasivas, no existe moneda alguna, se fomenta el trade de objetos y orbes, no hay magias inútiles ni todo el mundo va con la misma build, puedes craftearte todo tu equipo según tu criterio, etc...). La filosofía que mantienen es PLAY 2 WIN y free to play. Si os molan los juegos difíciles y el hardcore gaming, ya sabéis. Sobretodo muchisimo contenido (cada semana meten cosas nuevas, arreglos y mejoras), los cálculos del loot y la mecánica del juego son públicos, escuchan las peticiones de la gente y las implentan... una auténtica maravilla. No sé si les cambiará la mentalidad, pero ahora tienen todo mi respeto. PD. Si os mola el juego pillarles algún pack (aspectos customizables de personajes y magias, entre otros)... para echarles un cable ;).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
15, 2015
												Path of Exile is the most faithful successor to Diablo 2 that you'll find, including Diablo 3. While D3 took the approach of World of Warcraft's evolution, focusing on becoming more streamlined and more accessible than its predecessor, Path of Exile leans in the opposite direction. It's difficult, it's technical, and it's awesome. Truly, if feels as if everything that Diablo 3 did wrong, Path of Exile does right.The one area that PoE really diverges from the classic Diablo formula is in the active skill system. Active skills are granted by gem items. Skill gems gain experience and level up independantly of your character, and by combining active skill gems with "support gems" in equipment with appropriately-linked sockets, the combinations are vast.And that's what's really great about this game. The enormous scope of build variety and character customization. PoE's passive skill tree has hundreds and hundreds of nodes, and over the course of your character's career you'll have over 100 passive skill points to allocate in any direction and combination you see fit. Want to build a huge, muscle-bound Marauder that casts spells and holds wands? Want to create a Witch or Ranger that uses a Cyclone melee attack with a two-handed axe? Go for it. If you enjoy theorycrafting, you're bound to love this game.It's the most technical hack-and-slash ARPG out there, and likely the most unforgiving. The path to 100 is a long, long road, and once you're on the second and third difficulties you'll start losing experience with each death. It might get frustrating, but this is not a bad thing. The challenge and longevity this game presents is a breath of fresh air.And, somehow, the game is entirely free. There is -zero- "pay to win" here. You can buy extra stash tabs (though it's not at all necessary, they start you with four for free), but all the rest of the offered microtransactions are for purely cosmetic items. There is no way to get any sort of in-game boost or mechanical advantage by spending money.As a huge fan of the genre, PoE really feels like the most compelling offering as of right now.

content:
24, 2014
												TL;DR sum-up of PoE:  FTP Diablo 2.PoE is a FTP Diablo 2 knock off and I mean that in the most lovingly way possible.  Honestly, I'm surprised Blizzard hasn't gone after their asses.  From the character choices, graphics, minions (goat-men!!), hell, even the music, anyone who has played D2 will know immediately what I'm talking about. I, like many others, was crushed by what D3 turned into.  Looking for what D3 should have been?  Here's your answer.Is it really FTP?  yes.  The only, and I mean ONLY, things you can buy are cosmetic enhancements. Yay, glowing swords....Did I tell you there are almost daily competitions and races?  Well there are.  Examples:    Who can run the fastest through the game only using melee?  Oh you're a witch?  Well, better get swinging!    Unique dungeon crawls where you can't go home and fix your boo-boos or buy better equipment.  Use what you find, son!And don't worry, the playing field is leveled for this:  to do a race you must start with a brand new character.  Only your wits will help you prevail!  ...And lucky loot drops.I recommend this game, and for those nostalgic for D2; the first goat-bleat will warm your soul.  Happy left-button smashing!

												This game...Holy crap guys, let me tell you about its majesty.  Do you remember the days of Diablo 2?  The days where every choice from every level mattered.  Where each class had an amazing number of possibilities of gameplay?  Do you remember waiting a decade for Blizzard to make Diablo 3, only to be let down when the developers decided to do away with the part of the game you cared about the most: endless possibilities in decision making.  I sure do.  Enter Path of Exile.  This game takes character creation to the level of depth that you have always craved for.  7 character classes, ~1500 passive skills to choose, dozens of active skills to pick from with new ones being added periodically, and mini-expansion content every 4 months, well....its really a no-brainer.  Wait...you're already downloading it aren't you? ;-)

content:
ber 2, 2016
												Amazing high-quality action RPG with stellar graphics and a very dark and realistic artistic style. A major upgrade from the cookie cutter action RPGs on the market now... and this one is FREE.How Grinding Gear Games can release such a big-budget-production level game for free is a complete mystery to me. But I would gladly pay $20-$30 for such a robust and replayable game. The use of gems as skills and spells, combined with the unique barter system instead of gold, make this a completely different kind of RPG than has come before. And if you are a Christian (I am), then may I also point out that the primary religion in the game is based on one single "God" and you are often told that "God has a plan for you." Maybe that's not a big deal to some, but to those of us who get annoyed at how religion is portrayed in some games, this is a huge selling point.But regardless, this is not a game to miss ESPECIALLY since it's free. Go install now and you will see what I mean!

er 20, 2016
												This game will eat your life.I love and hate this game at the same time. It is starting to get dated, but new players will find so much to do that they won't even notice.The game has settled into two basic groups. 1) The 500+ hour player who is still struggles to make a character that is viable for end game content and 2) the 2000+ hour gamers who know every explot in the game and post videos on youtube about it.  Both groups still seem to have fun.The game has a steep learning curve for an AARPG, but can still be played with just basic understanding.  The most overwhelming thing is the skill tree. You will certainly mess up your first few characters, but that is part of the fun.It is the closest toa truly "free-to-play" game I've ever seen of its quality. The only real $ transactions are for asthetics and extra storage.  As long as you're not a pack rat, you never have to spend a dime. However, if you find that you put in 100+ hours on the game, you won't feel too bad dropping a little cash for storage and the money sorting system.Get it, play it, hate it, love it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2016
												This is one of the best games ever made, and when played on hardcore it is one of the most difficult, challenging and rewarding games of the modern era, a triumph over most games of this generation, and a callback to times when every player had to learn the game they were playing in order to succeed, rather than being catered to and handheld. Except this time you have an interactive community to help you along the way, as the game features trading, partying, player housing, and an 'interesting' global chat. And what a journey it will be, the atmosphere of this game feels like a blend of Dark Souls meets Diablo. Despite the graphics being pretty simple there's a ton of heart and fantastic art direction+flavour paving every step of the way. There's literally thousands upon thousands of ways to build your character. (Despite this 90%* of the community just plays CoC builds) *hyperboleThe best part? The game is free, aside from some purely aesthetic microtransactions which look very nice. No pay2win here. (Until you need more stash tabs i.e storage space) The community is one of the most diverse (for better & for worse) communities I've ever encountered, and the depth of this game is greater than most MMORPG's, despite this genre being an online ARPG. The difficulty scales to an absurd extent, you can never truly "Faceroll" every aspect of this game,(Unless you play CoC, in which case please uninstall--you're not a good player, stop uploading twinned boss map clear videos to Reddit, nobody cares--except for other CoC players) and there's just so much depth and replayable value to this game that I really can't recommend it enough. The endgame, on hardcore, is insanely fun and often times heartracing, with immense risk and reward being omnipresent throughout the experience. The more you play this game, the more you want to play it, and that is a surefire sign of both an addictive problem and a masterpiece. On the negative side of things, the early portion of this game is a total, unintuitive mess--if you're unfamiliar with the ARPG genre, or even if you're somewhat familiar with it, the game will likely feel far too overwhelming to bother with, it doesn't even bother trying to tutorialize you, and while the exploratory independence the game gives you is ultimately empowering, it's a little too vacuous for genuinely new players. Several of the game's mechanics & character features are amazingly in depth and customizable once you begin to grasp them, but unfortunately they also come off as very hard to understand initially, and even once you begin to understand them you'll likely fail to fully realize what you can do with them for quite some time. None of this is necessarily "bad", but it could certainly be offputting to a large demographic. The pace of the game is also painfully slow early on, this is especially true if you have no gear and if you're new to the game-most new players and even several veteran players don't know how to level efficiently, and waste a lot of excess time doing certain pointless side quests, picking up every useless item, killing every mob, doing irrelevant side areas, etc. Bluntly put, combat will not feel satisfying for a while, but when your build starts to come together and the enemies start to possess actually significant mechanics, boy oh boy does the world ever turn upside down. On top of that, the "true" game doesn't kick off until merciless difficulty, by which point you'll already have "beaten the campaign" twice, and this is presently very unintuitive to newer players, so a significant portion of the "playerbase" ends up "beating" the game (in their eyes) on normal and then never returning, even though the real experience hasn't even begun yet (Although regardless, at least these people get to experience the boss fight "Malachai", which is something you'll probably not soon forget). However, I'd still implore anyone who might turn away from the game because of these reasons to *just trudge through it* because, come merciless difficulty, come MAPS, it'll all prove to be deeply worth it. Once you get your first good unique item, once you 5 link or 6 link your first item, etc. etc., you'll have nowhere to go but up. That is, until your character dies and you angrily uninstall or reroll a CoC build. Screw CoC builds they're killing the game and trivializing the content, alright GGG you caught me this was all really an elaborate ruse with the actual intent of this review being nothing more than a rant about CoC builds. CoC builds are utterly faceroll and negate all strategic thought, difficulty, mechanics, and build variety involved in this game. Also nerf lightning coil and blade vortex. GOTY.

content:
y 18, 2014
												My game of choice when it comes to the top-down action RPG genre!It acts like a true spiritual successor to Diablo 2, when I started playing I was so pleased at how the game handled and looked. It's gritty and grimey and it feels like a slog through the legions of hell.Where the game really shines is the character creation and theorycraft aspects. You can spend a good hour or so deciding what kind of build you want and what sort of weapons and attacks you're going to use before even clicking that create a new character button. Thinking about how your passive stats and combination of attacks are all going to synergise with each other is all part of the fun. And yet if you don't want to do that it's fairly obvious where to go and what to get to make a successful build anyway (after a bit of practice)Highly recommended if you're a fan of the Diablo games, and even with the whole PoE vs D3 e-war I'd still try both and see what suits you, they are inherently different games. (this one is a whole lot cheaper though)

												This game is awesome.I played Diablo II religiously for a little over a decade (a few breaks here and there..) but I had to quit after bots just COMPLETELY INFESTED Battlenet. I bought Diablo III and wish I didn't spend $60 on it ...I will never play it again. I thought my days of playing Action RPGs were over ......until I found Path Of Exile. Its like the ......spiritual successor to Diablo2 but with enough twists and a few drastic differences (THE SKILL TREE) to keep me hooked. The icing on the cake is that this game is FREE. LOVE IT.Regardless, I highly recommend this game if you are into ARPGs, like Torchlight..or if you are a fan of classic Diablo games. It takes a little bit of time to get used to how the "currency"/skill tree/item socket systems work but once you get the hang of it ...you'll see the genius behind it. I just dont have enough time to play this game ...or any of my games for that matter D:9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2014
												Do you like action RPGS like Diablo 2, Torchlight, and Titan Quest? Yes? Then look no futher than Path of Exile.  This game is free to play in every sense of the word.  All money you can potentially spend is on cosmetics and such.  If you like it, it is worth supporting them as they have made an enjoyable game that never hounds you to spend money.  One playthrough will take around 20-25 hours, but you will likey want to go back and choose a new character to play with.The biggest difference with this game as opposed to other action RPGS is that the skill you have are tied to gems that you pick up and then slot into armor/weapons.  These gems level up by you using them.  You can unslot them and then reslot other gems as you see fit (they maintain their levels).  This allows you to really experiment with builds while not being restricted to specific skills or armor.Just give it a go. You will like it!

content:
r 28, 2013
												One of the most addicting and rewarding Action Role Playing games to date. It features an extensive passive tree with over hundreds of possibilities with extreme character progression and builds.The game features 7 different classes each with their own unique abilities and play styles which caters to any individuals type of play-through, whether you are a brute tank (The Marauder) or a necromancer witch who can use arcane magic and call upon the dead for help.The best feature of the game is that it is free to play! There are in-game purchases but they're merely cosmetic items which don't effect the balancing of the game as the developers have been strict on making a fair game.You will almost certainly have a good time leveling up with your friends.  As there is no gold in this game, You may get turned off by the extreme reliance on trading that is a consequence of the frustratingly unrewarding item drops and PoE's annoyingly random orb system The game itself looks rather nice, even if it isn't up to par with the AAA games out there, it is a free to play and not 60$.All in all, I'd say pick this one up! It's free after all and if you enjoy ARPG's then you'll enjoy this one!

content:
ry 2, 2014
												+Addictive ARPG Gameplay+Multiple Character Options+Coherent ARPG Story+Free-To-Play without the Freemium-Pacing drags towards the endPath of Exile is the best Free-to-Play game on the PC market.  The monetization of the game is never shoved into your face and the game never feels like it is giving you a lesser experience for playing without spending.The Action Role Playing Game (ARPG) elements are excelent as the various special abilities express variabilty in game mechanics while providing satisfying feedback in the form of crunchy-gory slaughter.  While there is plenty of good enemy variability throughout the campaign, your primary tactics will most likely not vary until you come accross large groups of enemies or platoons that mix range and melee combatants.The character customization is limited to the items you wear and the sprawling skill tree that makes up the leveling system for the game.  While skill gems provide the meat of experience in terms of move sets, the skill tree simply determines what weapons and armor you can equip while providing percentage bonus to your damage and attack speeds.All character classes are viable, however, it is important to note their specialties to best equip and advance your character for optimal slaying.  While the game is not necessarily difficult, deaths become common when you make haphazard or impatient mistakes to bring the fight to a large group of enemies.  Boss encounters can seem daunting at first, however, once you understand to eliminate their followers and then carefully avoid their primary attack, the fights become very manageable.Path of Exile introduces some innovations or rather differing mechanics for bartering and potion use.  When you trade an item into a vendor, you recieve peices of identifying scrolls or alchemy gems that can be used to identify or make magic items respectively.  This displaces the importance of accumulated wealth into a more free form experimentation with getting better gear as you can often make a better item from a non-magical item and a few alchemy gems.  Potions are recharged from slaying enemies rather than consumed on an individual basis, which adjusts your tactics as you become heavily damaged.Overall, I think Path of Exile is a great game, free-to-play or not.  I found it more engaging than Diablo III and Torchlight II, however, your experience might vary based on how the art style and story appeals to your tastes.  The game, though, is just fun and should be at least tried.[GET ASAP]

content:
ry 10, 2014
												Awesome game. Feels like the true successor to Diablo 2, as it still has a massive amount of customization you can do to a character (unlike Diablo 3's kid-friendly stat system).The skill system is ripped straight from Final Fantasy VII's Materia system. Your skills are slotted into your gear and can only be used if they are slotted. I think it's a fantastic use of the system that works great in an ARPG. This increases the customization because any class can use any skill, assuming you have the stats to back it up. It allows for some crazy cross-class builds. Combine that with the MASSIVE passive skill tree (Google it and see for yourself) and you'll be theorycrafting your perfect build for a long, long time.To top it off, the microtransactions are purely aesthetic, so the game is not even remotely pay to win or pay to get epic loot quick. You still have to earn your gear, levels, and skills.This is the perfect successor to Diablo 2.

content:
ry 2, 2014
												This game is very fun. It keeps you stuck to the game, and never wanting to stop playing. I must confess: I've only played an hour of this game, but out of that hour was one of the best hours I have ever had. In the first part, you basicly just choose a class, big deal, right? Well, you get shipwrecked, then you talk to a guy, and fend off a horde of the undead. After killing some more undead, you get some more items, then, comes out a boss. He is acually pretty hard, so, I recommend leveling up once or twice and getting some gear before you fight him. After that, you get in a town, and then your adventure starts from there! You can do some sidequests there, later gaining people's trust. After a while, you realize how far and how good you are doing with this game, trust me, this game is amazing. The controls are pretty easy to handle. The gameplay, however, is laggy at times, but eventually stops. Also, one bad thing about your character, when you pick your main weapon, you're bound to want to get another one, but you realize it is not the same with your old weapon(s). For example, I had a rusted sword and a claw. I wanted to try out a bow and arrow. I found out that I had to un-equip both weapons(duh) and equip the bow. After I did that, I realized it wasn't the same with my life stealing claw and sword, so, I switched. So, I strongly suggest that you should get this game. Also, one thing, I think that this game is somewhat similar to League of Legends or Dota 2. That's what I think, I don't know about the rest of you. Anyway, download Path of Exile, and be prepared to fight and be addicted to this game!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
y 10, 2014
												I thought I would try and write up a few words about this game, as I really enjoy the ARPG games and played through most of them (Diablo I & II, Titan Quest & IT, Torchlight I & II, Van Helsing, and only don't have D3 due to cost - though this may change when the patch comes) and for me, the Daddy of them all has been Titan Quest. I probably sunk 200+ hrs in that and Immortal Throne (they don't show on my Steam games as I had them pre-steam and loved the game so much I rebought them on Steam) and played through the game on all three difficulty ratings. So how does Path of Exile square up to these other great ARPG's? Bloody good actually. Really bloody good.Graphics The effects on everything are superb, the gem levelling, the elemental attacks, the frozen or burning mob/player effects, the animations for mobs blinking, tunnelling, dissolving, ghosting, all of it. The backdrops for locations (towns, villages, caves, forests, battlegrounds) are lush with a huge amount of detail, the characters look excellent, with a large amount of clothing variants.Maps Excellent. How many ways can you actually put dead ends into a seemingly open ended area? You will be surprised, and they do it very well. With some much detail, the minimap adds yellow 'corridors' to show connecting areas in case the foliage or camera angle is in your way, and there are plenty of variations - cave textures are repeated more often than not, but I suppose its quite hard to come up with new ways to portray rocks, so I will let them off that.Mobs A Huge amount of variation with the usual casters, fighters and ranged mobs, and then mixed abilities, casting, teleporting, swarms, etc. There is a nice mix of normal and yellow bosses, and then end of act bosses. I think I would have liked to see more 'bigger than yellow but less than end of act bosses' like in TQ, but other than that, jolly good indeed.Skill Tree & Classes Ah, the bread and butter of all ARPG's, the skill tree. This is where PoE fails, as it has no skill tree at all! Instead, it has a freaking skill WEB. No mere tree for this game, but a spiders web that depending on class, your start point changes. You gain skill points per level and for completing some quests and you can customise your (one of 6) classes to a stupid amount of variations. I thought TQ ability to combine two classes and then pick and choose from their respective trees brilliantly varied, but this is something else.Loot Ah, the loot. You want to pour of the minute of the items found, min/maxing to gain resists/hp/regen/dps? You will spend hours doing so. You want the ability to create and improve items? You will spend hours doing so. You want to take your item as you like the look of it, wipe it, and new stats, add sockets and reforge links? You will spend hours doing so. Like most other ARPGs, you never seem to find the right item for your class, but this only makes you want to farm and then replay the whole game again on the next difficulty. There are sockets to add spells and effects to your attacks, and gems to improve the quality of the items - so the combinations of items available is staggering.Overall So add them all together and what have you got? A cracking game, and even diehard 'nothing will beat Titan Quest' ARPGers will admit that this is fantastic. The game itself is free, and you really do not need to spend a penny to enjoy it - I may drop some money on it to say thanks rather than any real need to want a shiny effect on my hat or glowing footprints (even though they do look smart) A fourth act or more locations per act may have tipped it over the edge, but this is right up there, surpassing both Torchlights and Van Helsing, and right on the tailcoats of TQ. There is simply not an excuse to not download this on Steam right now.

You want to pour of the minute of the items found, min/maxing to gain resists/hp/regen/dps? You will spend hours doing so. You want the ability to create and improve items? You will spend hours doing so. You want to take your item as you like the look of it, wipe it, and new stats, add sockets and reforge links? You will spend hours doing so. Like most other ARPGs, you never seem to find the right item for your class, but this only makes you want to farm and then replay the whole game again on the next difficulty. There are sockets to add spells and effects to your attacks, and gems to improve the quality of the items - so the combinations of items available is staggering.Overall So add them all together and what have you got? A cracking game, and even diehard 'nothing will beat Titan Quest' ARPGers will admit that this is fantastic. The game itself is free, and you really do not need to spend a penny to enjoy it - I may drop some money on it to say thanks rather than any real need to want a shiny effect on my hat or glowing footprints (even though they do look smart) A fourth act or more locations per act may have tipped it over the edge, but this is right up there, surpassing both Torchlights and Van Helsing, and right on the tailcoats of TQ. There is simply not an excuse to not download this on Steam right now.

content:
21, 2014
												First of all let me say that i totally recommend this game to everybody who played Diablo III and got utterly disappointed by it. Path of Exile is comparable to older Diablo titles in its atmosphere and skill level and it is of course free to play. I always use PoE as an example for one of the best f2p titles out there since there is not a single pay to win aspect in the game. All you can buy with real life money are cosmetic changes to your character or more stash tabs to store items (not to be confused with your actually relevant character inventory!). Path of Exile offers  the standard action RPG game style with serveral  acts and several playthroughs, one a little harder then the other. For the first few characters that system never gets boring, but it lacks a bit of long time motivation, especially since the late game aspect of the game (maps you can find and replay zones on a higher level through them) gets boring after some time, too. PoE has something to offer for every kind of ARPG player. Those who simply want to play a hack and slay game can do so, but also players who like to think a lot about optimizing their build will be satisfied thanks to the unique and massive skill tree.There really is no reason not to check out Path of Exile, especially since it is totally free!

content:
, 2014
												Path of Exile is one of the best games I've ever played. PoE is a free to play game, but unlilke most other f2p games out there, there is absolutely no way to gain any bonuses or anything by paying money. The only thing you get by paying money is cool skins for your gear. It doesn't have have any effect on the actual gameplay. The game is quite complicated, but that is what keeps me coming back for more, as there is a near-infinite amount of combinations of skills and character builds, most of them with significantly different playstyles. While the campaign does get a little old after a while, (on one character, you have to repeat the campaign 3 times on different difficulties), Grinding Gear Games has said that they have more content in the works that will eliminate this, with a new act scheduled for release in early 2015. Overall, I would rate PoE 10/10, a must-play.

ry 23, 2015
												Poked a dead body and a giant shield fell out of its stomach.11/10 Would poke dead people againBut in all seriousness, this is a great game. It has a good community, enough players that you can always find a party to play with, but the game is just as much fun to play alone if soloing is more your style. it is COMPLETELY F2P, with the only paid content being cosmetics. The difficulty curve is just steep enough to be challenging, without repeatedly reducing you to pounding the keys and screaming incoherently into your mic. The controls and gameplay take some getting used to, but if you've played similar games before you should have no trouble. One thing i found interesting is that there is no in-game currency. Instead, items are purchased using a barter system that uses items you can find while playing, and these items have their own uses as well. You start out with one of six classes, which each have their own strengths and weaknesses. However, the skills and abilities of these classes are infinitly customizable, giving you the freedom to play however you want. The story is not the most detailed I've seen, not by a long shot, but it's definitely there. All in all, this is one of the best games I've played in a long time, and i would definitely recommend that you play it.Serious rating: 9.5/10

content:
2015
												An excellent action RPG for all Diablo 2 fans out there. For me Diablo 3 was kind of a disappointment, long story short: the loot didn't feel exciting. In Path of Exile I actually expect to find useful items. I constantly find myself getting excited over a rare item dropping and even some basic white items for crafting.Another thing I disliked about Diablo 3 was the auction house, it just ruined the trading aspect for me since it completely removed any and all interaction with other people. Maybe I'm weird but I enjoy discussing prices with other people and actually doing the trading. Even with most people setting up a semi-automated shop via the use of "Procurement", you still get to interact with other people and there's bartering to be done.PoE has a microtransaction shop where you can buy cosmetic effects (armor skins, effects for your weapons, pets etc.) and stash tabs. You could argue the stash tabs affect the game in a way that could be interpreted as pay-to-win but I disagree. You can play the game just fine with the free 4 tabs you get by default, you just have to pay inventory tetris a bit more and choose what items you wish to keep more carefully. The skins you buy for your armor/weapons are also transferrable between items and characters, so you don't have to buy another one to apply the effect to another item.The skill tree and skill gem systems allow for a wide variety of builds and I find it nicely flexible to fit whatever I want out of a build at the time. It's more than just unlocking a fireball; you can divide that fireball to several fireballs each dealing a bit less damage but that way gaining more AoE, you can then add other types of damage to it or even make it a damage-over-time focused fireball instead of explosions, if you so wish.In conclusion I wholeheartedly recommend this game for anyone looking for a good ARPG experience. It starts out a bit slow but trust me, it's worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Best action RPG out there right now, but not without its problems:PoE requires too much dedication for hard working students and people with jobs or a family who want to maintain a healthy lifestyle. If you don't have a lot of time on your hands, you're better off playing some other game because you won't get much out of PoE.The skill tree doesn't offer as much freedom as it first appears to. While the overall selection does greatly affect how your character works under the hood, they are still passive skills, most of which are just tiny percentage buffs and seriously underwhelming on their own.I'm not a fan of D3, but the active skills in PoE do not satisfy like D3's do. There aren't any active skills that really make me want to build a PoE character.In PoE you tend to build a character around one attack and spam that single one until you're blue in the face. Other action RPGs typically offer combined use of more active skills.PoE is a thinking person's game, challenging, huge depth in its mechanics. It takes a long time and a lot of reading to learn how to create strong characters and it takes forever to get characters to a high level. The learning process is a joy, but respeccing isn't really doable.The game changes a lot. If you leave the game and return after some months, you'll need to relearn wat makes a strong character, and all your character's passive skill trees will have been reset because the game's skill tree was likely updated. Your characters won't function until you reinvest those skillpoints. After returning to the game you likely won't know the current trade value of items.The game doesn't comfortably let you take a few months off and then come back.They went too crazy with the socket colours and linked sockets. While fun at first, the impossibly low odds of getting the right sockets and links on your gear become an annoying limiting factor to how you build your character. Specifically, part of the problem is that the type of defence stat (armor, energy shield, or evasion) on a gear item determines what socket colour is most likely to show up on it. Active kills are gems that need to be socketed before you can use them, and they will only fit in sockets of the matching colour. This effectively forces you to focus on a specific defence type based on what active skills you want to use, severely restricting the endless freedom that the passive skill tree initially appears to provide.

content:
er 1, 2013
												This is a great Diablo clone with an intriguing twist on old game mechanics. It's well-balanced with an astounding range of customizability. The most important element is the lack of real currency, which is usually a resource that is never well balanced in any game. They just did away with it entirely, using a less formal bartering system, which actually requires you to conserve your resources. Customizing your skills is equally engaging. Meanwhile, the difficulty has a nice curve to it, requiring you to seek a balance of protection and offense. I commend the developers on a very intelligently designed game!

Meanwhile, the difficulty has a nice curve to it, requiring you to seek a balance of protection and offense. I commend the developers on a very intelligently designed game!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 2, 2015
												Whenever I was young, I used to drop thousands of hours into Diablo II. Every waking moment of my life was spent grinding my way to max level on all characters, gathering immense amounts of loot, and playing around with friends for hours at a time. The game offered me massive amounts of reward, enjoyability, and replayability. So, naturally, when I heard that Blizzard was coming out with a new Diablo game, I thought my prayers had been answered. No more watered-down Triple-A games; this was it, my love of gaming was supposed to pool back into me with Diablo III. Then I was disappointed - severely disappointed. Diablo III was nothing like the game I had played back in the day and I couldn't understand how Blizzard could screw up something so beautiful. With nothing left to turn to, I sauntered about the internet, searching for the ARPG that would take me away from the pain Blizzard had brought to myself. Torchlight was decent, but nothing too special. Drakensang was okay, but nothing to write home about. Then I stumbled upon Path of Exile. I was hesitant, to be honest with you. The game looked solid from the screenshots, but I could never really know unless I downloaded it. Let me tell you, after 400 hours of this game, this is completely raising the standards for ARPGs and nothing (as of the date on this review) could ever come close to the quality of this game.  A massive skill tree, making for complete build diversity.  Overwhelmingly brilliant, lore-based atmospheres.  Visually stunning; what Diablo should have been.  Endless amounts of fun, especially with friends.  Developers that actually care! Amazing F2P business model.I will forever be loyal to Path of Exile. This gave me my love of gaming back. This is what Diablo III should have been and wishes it was. If you're not sold yet, go ahead and download the game for a trial run. Every bit of content is free and there's nothing to lose. I guarantee you won't ever regret it.Update for Atlas of WorldsMy review was done before the Atlas of Worlds expansion hit and I would like to reassure anyone wondering: yes, this expansion is amazing and, yes, the game is still just as good as it has always been.

content:
ry 1, 2015
												Path of Exile is a FREE 2 PLAY!! action roleplaying hack and slash game comparable to the likes of Diablo 2 and the Dungeon Siege games. You play as an exile facing the harshness of the continent of Wraeclast, fighting enemies and exploring the land but mostly HOARDING items. The game allows to experience the story through 6 classes from the start plus another one that is unlocked by completing the storyline. It uses a third person or an overhead view and combat is lucid and unstiff. The world of Wraeclast is really beautiful, the dark artstyle compliments the tone. The skill tree is very diverse allowing vast customization of your character. The weapons are very diverse through different modifiers and items are tradable amongst players. The game has a PvP and Co-op options which allows you to interact with others or your friends through your journey across Wraeclast. Let's talk about the free2play model, it is not Pay2Win. Everything that you can purchase is cosmetics or stash space which does not affect the game. The game is regularly updated and devs seem very dedicated to the game. Rating: 92/100

content:
er 2, 2016
												 Has a slow ramp up, but a good skill cieling.  The game is heavy on the theorycrafting so expect to spend a few hours on the web looking at builds if you want to get the most out of your character.   Respecs are done through rare ingame loot, it is not practical to respec most characters, so expect to create multiple characters over time.After a hundred or so hours of playtime it becomes necessary to spend a few bucks on inventory/character expansion slots.  If you find yourself spending more time, you can expect to spend $20 to $30 for quality of life improvements.   Other than that microtransactions are pay to cool not pay to win.There are full price AAA titles that provide less entertainment, absolutley no reason not to give this game a go.

												My old reviews have way too outdated information.This game has grown so much over 3 or so years after release and I have seen it longer than that since I was in early Open Beta.The game DOES give you more resources for damage and defenses making it easier to make those crazy ♥♥♥ builds that were not possible in the past. Customization is better than ever now that we have Ascendancy classes (huge subclasses bonuses) and the end game is about to get an overhaul with the next Atlas of Worlds expantion.Still a "Must Try" title.Also, don't lose hope/interest if you don't defeat the almighty Hillock, Brutus and/or Merveil ;)Just keep trying and you will find a great game that will make your wife leave you.

content:
16, 2016
 IntroductionPath Of Exile is an Action RPG Hack and Slash game that is true gem within its genre. Nobody should ever pass the opportunity to try the game if they are into Hardcore games with learning curves that come out of game experience. The game offers a gigantic Passive Skill tree that will enable any sort of build you might come up with. This game will please alot of thinkers as long as they are willing to understand the rules of the game but at the same time can also please the most casual of the players that just want to be there for the action.The Pros: The Combat System: Path of Exile has a unique way of combining gems. Gems represent castable skills that can either be buffing auras , statuses , combat spells , multipliers and so on. Those gems can be equiped into sockets that your gear has, combining those spells if met said requirements can make them more powerful, for example you can add a gem that allows you to fire more projectiles with your main combat ability , or you can make the projectiles have a chain effect on the enemies. This allows for insane theory crafting and build creations and cycling through many skills you can find what you truly want to play by testing it yourself or simply following guides of other experienced players on the official forums which is what I would recommend for newcommers!  Replay Value: The game offers 4 Acts Of Story , 3 Difficulties and Endgame Maps , Races that last from hours to weeks and can reward you with Permanent Items/Skins. Two Core leagues for both Casual and Hardcore players Hardcore being the one with Permanent death as result. And season leagues that last for 3 months in which you start-over with everybody else and they have their own unique mods that change the gameplay. With the Passive Tree system and the way that Skills work you can made infinite builds on any character you like , either make your own builds or test the shared ones which you can find at the official forums of the game. Refreshing Gameplay Elements: The 3 Month League system is a great feature that more games should use. Giving the original gameplay a new taste every now and then and reseting the ladders allowing people to re-compete from ground 0 is a great way to make people enjoy the game and the better part is that if you are not interested in such a thing you can always stick with Permanent leagues. This gives a further meaning to the infinite builds you can already create because in different scenarios they may work better or worse. Aside from all this, these leagues have achievements of their own which by completion you can recieve awards at the end that you would otherwise need to pay real money for. Developer relationship with Community: If Grinding Gear Games has done anything right aside from their game itself is listening to the community and delivering. Their plan is to do a content update every 6 months and an expansion one the next cycle. The game is F2P and has no P2W elements at all , yet it works really well for them. That is a phenomenom rarely seen in the F2P market nowdays and is certainely honourable.The Cons:Difficulty Curve and Player Taste: While this is not necessarily a negative feature of the game its worth noting that the game is really punishing. That can be either the beauty of the game for some , or their breaking point to quit the game and move on to the next one. While the game can be played casually , if you are seeking to play in a Hardcore league you better get ready to die, LOTS of times and then find yourself knowing the limits of your character and the strengths of certain monsters.Monotonic Visual theme and Soundtracks: While the game itself looks gorgeous in many ways and has a decent ammount of soundtracks. If you find yourself becoming a veteran you may feel a sense of dullness because the dark theme around the game starts to feel very monotonic over many hours played. With that being said at first glance you will certainely love the game if you are into the dark theme and wont have a problem, but if you end up playing alot you will notice that in the gameplay. Aside from that, specificly for soundtracks. They fit thematically really well but I cannot personally say that anything really stands out.Co-Op cross Continent can be brutal: The game offers a big selection of servers with realtime ping check before entering in and no borders in between (Meaning you can swap to any server at anytime and keep your progress) , the grouping system makes the Leader of the Group the host of the instance so if you are planning to play with friends from a different continent (on a game like this which death could be a matter of half a second) having low and stable ping is really important , it can be really troublesome.ConclussionI do recommend this game for both the casual and the hardcore gamers. The game offers huge ammount of unique playtime whether you plan on sticking around for long and being active or hopping in the game here and there. If you are a fan to the genre this is a welcoming game as it has many elements from many popular games such as Diablo and Torchlight which has taken direct inspiration from. This is one of the games that have to be in your "Must Try" collection so if you decide on playing , best of luck to you , Exile.

content:
12, 2014
												A love letter to Diablo 2, and the deepest Action RPG I have ever played.  On top of that, they add things to make it deeper faster than I can keep up.  I play solo exclusively.It's not perfect, but for fans of the genre, I give it a 9.5/10.  For everyone else I give it a fair (non-inflated) score of 8.3.  The only noticeable problem is rubber-banding, though it also has a few telltale signs of being developed by a small studio, such as a few errors here and there in the dialogues, or voice-acting errors (incorrect emphasis, non-volume-normalized transitions showing that two recordings have been patched together into one, etc.).  Nothing that is likely to bother you, unless you are as anal as I am about these things and/or extremely observant.  One or two voice actors are terrible, but that's probably noticeable because most of the remaining did a superb job.If you hate action RPGS, then this one won't change your mind.  (Sorry.)  But if you're curious, give it a try, since it's free.None of the microtransactions are pay2win except for additional stash space, but they give you enough to start with that you won't feel cramped until you have multiple characters.  At that point you will no longer mind shelling out some cash for the game.  I think the developers have more than earned it, and you are likely to feel the same way at that point.The remainder of the business model consists of cosmetic microtransactions: costumes, weapon/skill effects, and pets.  But the vanilla costumes and effects are good enough to enjoy this game completely, in my opinion.Protip: Wait for a premium stash tab bundle sale.  Then spend $30-$40 on tabs, and that's probably all you will need for many years; i.e., you've essentially bought the game for yourself.  And that's a lot less than you spent just to be disappointed by Diablo 3.

content:
r 21, 2015
												Overview: Path of ExileThis game is technically an MMO, but you will seldom encounter other players unless you choose to invite them to a squad with you. If it weren't for global chat, you may or may not realize that anyone else even owns the game while you're not in a major city. The gameplay is very dungeon-crawler(esque) with a good deal of lootfest and skill tree elements. Storyline: lol didn't read it, nobody has time for that (doubting anyone has time to read reviews either, but these devs deserve the time it took to give the review). Difficulty: initially there is only a normal difficulty, but a character can access a higher difficulty (cruel, the merciless) after beating the quest line on their current difficulty. Additionally, you can create normal or hardcore characters, the difference being that hardcore characters recieve better loot, but on death, they convert to standard characters, and all their gear becomes standard gear (and cannot be traded back to a hardcore character).Pros: 1) Microtransactions aren't needed for late game.. in fact, there is nothing you can buy with money that results in an in-game advantage beyond a larger storage chest. 2) Character Balance and Variety. There are nearly infinite amounts of viable character builds and skills, not just 2-3 "use these or always lose" web builds for "op classes" - from what I've seen, the classes are surprisingly well balanced.3) Community. There are usually a lot of people chatting in global, and many people are willing to provide help either in-game or just give advice on items if you're inclined to ask. As always on the internet, there's a healthy amount of salt, and a few trolls, but such is the price we pay for gaming with other people.4) Audio. The ambient sounds and the soundtracks for the game are both excellent, and the character attack sound effects manage to avoid being irritating although you end up hearing the same ones hundreds of times in the course of an hour.5) Details. The devs clearly spent enough time in other games to understand what's annoying in an mmo, and they did their best to remove those elements. Most notably, potions don't clutter your inventory - instead, you can carry up to 5 potions, which refill as you slay enemies. The game doesn't have currency, instead players trade with chaos/fusing orbs, materials which can actually be used to upgrade items, rather than exclusively be used for buying and selling.Cons:1) Repetition. Although the creatures and attacks change, but essentially every level plays out the same. It's quite grind-heavy in that even if you progress through new areas as soon as you finish the quests, the actual gameplay remains redundant.2) Actually.. being bored by the redundancy of combat is my only complaint. Although boredom is a death sentence in most games, I think I'll still keep playing this one... and even if you do quit if you become bored, there's easily 20 hours of early-game content which you'll probably complete before reaching that point.

Oomph, they don't feel very powerful at the moment. (Disclaimer: The abilities are not weak, it is just they look weak)The entrances to places need to look better (The white box that appears over the entrances blocks what is there to be seen, it's intruding on the atmosphere of the game!)The map is pretty bad looking, it needs a graphical update (It works, but it looks bad)In short: I would highly recommend this game, I'm beginning to like it more than Diablo 3 at the moment, and I've only played it for a bit.Definitely get this game, it's free and it's great fun, what else do you need in a game?!

												This is a very solid ARPG, at this point it has become a cliche to say that it's a better successor to Diablo 2 than Diablo 3. The passive skill system may seem a bit weird at first, but it's a very good gameplay mechanic once you get used to it. Loot is also great, you should have no problem keeping your characters equipped nicely through persistent playing.Active skills are realized through gems, which you can freely remove from items after inserting them. Gems level up on their own, and can additionally be "augmented" with special support gems, which is overall a very fresh mechanic that works quite well.The best part is that there are no "pay to win" mechanics in this game, everything you can buy with real cash is cosmetic (with the exception of extra chest pages and character slots, but you're given enough of those for free anyway).The only area where the game is a bit weak is the story, it doesn't really shine with anything special there. This personally doesn't bother me as I play ARPGs primarily for the gameplay, I didn't even pay much attention to what was going on in Diablo 2's storyline. Even POE's story beats the quality of writing in Diablo 3 though :)

content:
21, 2015
												This game is so ridiculously good.  I started playing it in beta before it was on Steam after a friend introduced me to it, and the game has grown so much since then.  It has so many unique things to offer.  For those who want to know more...I will attempt to explain some of the things you will need to know from the start.  It may sound daunting, but it isn't as difficult to pick up as it sounds.A quick sidenote.  Yes, it's free.  No, it's not pay to win.  There isn't a single thing in the store that gives an advantage over other players.  It's filled with a ton of cosmetics, bank tabs, and character slots.  None of which you will actually need, they're just nice to have.For starters, there is the incredibly large passive skill tree with over 1300 passives on it.  All 7 characters are positioned in different spots on this skill tree.  The "pure" characters are positioned on the passive skill tree directly within the three core attributes.  The Marauder with strength, the Ranger with dexterity, and the Witch (my personal favorite) with intelligence.  The "hybrid" characters are the Duelist with strength/dexterity, the Templar with strength/intelligence, the Shadow with dexterity/intelligence, and the Scion (who isn't unlocked until later in the game) with strength/dexterity/intelligence.  There are also jewels which can be socketed into the passive skill tree, that grant various buffs and abilities and sometimes alter other passives within a certain radius.Next is your equipment.  Weapons, armor, accessories, and flasks.  There's a ton of possible stats you can get, and every weapon and armor piece will have a random amount of colored sockets on them, some linked together and some not (I will explain that more later as it ties in with your active skills).  As for the flasks, you can have up to five equipped and those are what you use to replenish your health and mana.  There's also some with a more niche purpose.Your active skills come in the form of skill gems.  These gems come in three colors: red, blue, and green.  And what colors are those sockets on your weapons and armor?  Red, blue, and green.  You get skill gems as drops and quest rewards, and then socket them in the apropriately colored slot on your equipment.  A piece of equipment can have anywhere from one to six sockets on it, depending on a number of factors.  And if multiple sockets are linked together, then the gems in those sockets can work together.  For example, you could have a skill gem that lets you raise a zombie, and then another one linked to that which makes your zombie do more damage.The story is great, the soundtrack is cool, the NPCs are awesome.  The game has full voice acting.  Overall things have a really dark and gritty theme to it, and it's done very well.  The enemies and bosses and even the areas get progressively more and more creepy.  There's currently a total of four acts, each with their own unique things to offer.There is so much more I could talk about, I've barely scratched the surface.  The Forsaken Masters, corrupted areas, Divination cards, hideouts, leagues/events, the barter system (no actual currency in the game), all the items that can be used to alter your equipment, plus the special maps for endgame...but you can learn it for yourself when you play.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 10, 2015
5/5 ::::: Essential PlayI've never played Diablo 3, but this game makes me not mind. Surely the best action RPG on the market, and it's free. How can you not give it a try? If you preferred the skill trees of Diablo II over the third entry's approach, you have to check out Path of Exile: certainly one of the most enormous and complex skill trees I've ever encountered in a game, though I've heard the meta is apparently much more simple.There's a fairly crazy amount of depth to this game. Passive skills are earned on the skill tree, but active skills are found in the form of gems, items that are socketed (and unsocketed) into your equipment. There seems to be a lot of complexity to the system and I've barely scratched the surface myself. Beginners will definitely want to research good builds online at some point. Then there's the player hideout which you can customize to your hearts' content, and a whole world of upper-level play I haven't reached yet; you could say that the game hasn't really even begun on your first playthrough.It plays like a single player game, but it's online. I haven't grouped into any parties or traded yet, so the most noticeable online feature for me is the global chat. The one significant edit I'm bothering to make in this review after investing 100+ hours is to say: chat is addicting, but the community is pretty toxic. Channel 1 is the worst, but every channel is full of your typical Internet nihilists. This being one of my first online games, I have no idea if this is to be expected. Luckily, there is the incredible feature to turn global chat OFF. It completely transforms the game, I recommend giving it a try! Difficulty is challenging throughout; players may well breeze through earlier sections, but find themselves needing to rethink things once the difficulty ramps up at various points, especially with the relatively recently-added fourth act. Finally, did I mention it's free? Give it a try; you may just find your new obsession.
